characters: INT/EXT. MAMA LUCAS'S TEANECK, N.J. HOUSE
F56 INT/EXT. TENT / JUNGLE ARMY LZ

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tall, handsome man in a dark suit emerges from a Lincol Towncar and enters a small, basement R&B/Jazz club.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He approaches a booth, says something in the din to the m there, then calmly shoots them and exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bumpy Johnson, an elderly but still sturdy black man, elegantly dressed - cashmere overcoat, gloves, Homburg - stands in falling snow atop a flatbed truck - as he does every Thanksgiving - tossing down turkeys to the poor - like a benign king. Legend:   Harlem A younger man, the gunman from the club - Frank Lucas - Bumpy's driver/bodyguard/collector/protege - watches from below.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. STREET / DISCOUNT EMPORIUM
dialogues.text: Whispering gunfire from a television set veiled by foreground snow: Soldiers in the jungles of Vietnam in 1970. A rich, cultured, authoritative voice offers:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the problem. This is what's wrong with America. The war footage multiplies by twenty: a stack of TVs with price tags dangling from the knobs behind a display windo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's gotten so big you can't find your way. People on the sidewalk, out of respect or fear, part to l Frank and Bumpy and Bumpy's German shepherd pass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The corner grocery's a supermarket. Candy store's a MacDonald's. And this place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's the pride of ownership here? Where's the personal service? Does anybody work here? Inside, the emporium is vast, with aisles that seem to stretch off into infinity. The TVs give way to a display window full of Japanese stereo componentry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What right do they have cutting out the suppliers, pushing all the middlemen out, buying direct from the manufacturer - Sony this, Toshiba that, all them Chinks - putting Americans out of work? He's not really asking Frank, so Frank doesn't answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What am I supposed to do with a place like this, Frank? Who am I supposed to ask for, the assistant manager? (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the problem. This is the way it is now: You can't find the heart of anything to stick the knife. Bumpy stops before a display of cameras and stares in. They're all pointed at him as a pain grips his chest and sinks to his knees. Frank kneels down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it? Bumpy seems unable to speak, looks to Frank confused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somebody call an ambulance! But the store suddenly seems empty. Frank yells into the emporium but can't be heard above the Muzak and the cash registers ringing up sales Bumpy will never see a piece o Looking up at Frank, Bumpy manages weakly -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget it, Frank. No one's in charge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Limousines from the funeral disgorge mourners: family, friends, celebrities, politicians. Cops on horseback move through the enormous crowd that has gathered to watch. FB agents in cars snap pictures with long lenses of Italian mobsters like Albert Tosca.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - whose passing has brought together a who's who of mourners on this chilly afternoon. The Governor has come down. The mayor of New York - its Chief of Police and Commissioner - sports and entertainment luminaries - A white Bentley pulls up, disgorging Jackie Fox - the original Superfly - and his entourage. With his trademark tinted Gucci glasses on, he happily poses for anyone with camera - including the Feds - before going inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The report continues on a TV no one's really watching her a March of Time-like history of Bumpy Johnson, famed Harl gangster, Robin Hood and killer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was a Great Man, according to the eulogies. A giving man. A man of the people. No one chose to include in their remembrances the word most often associated with Ellsworth Bumpy Johnson: Gangster. Sitting off by himself in Bumpy's elegant garden apartmen heretofore his private sanctuary, Frank surveys the mourn circling the place like vultures: Tango Black, a huge brute, scavenging the catered food an tended bar ... Jackie Fox, surrounded by his ever-present coterie of sycophants ... Albert Tosca, an elegant Italia capo, and an underling, Rossi, at the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: White wine, please. A white man who looks like a banker - and is - sits down next to Frank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How you doing, Frank?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a loss. (Frank nods)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How are you otherwise?   Things okay financially?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Frank doesn't say. It feels unseemly to him to be talking about money here. He watches Tango carelessly set a water glass of ice on an antique inlaid chess table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bumpy set something up for you? Frank excuses himself without an answer, crosses to where Tango left the glass, and sets it on a coaster.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Frank, get me an ashtray while you're at it. Bumpy's German shepherd watches as Frank reaches into his jacket, revealing a gun nestled in its shoulder holster. takes out a handkerchief, wipes the condensation dry, ope a drawer and removes an ashtray. He holds it out to Tango who isn't sure it's not a dare and decides to wander off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you're hurting, Frank.    So am I. Frank sits back down with Charlie Williams, an older dope man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You going to be all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure Bumpy never told you, but he made me promise, anything ever happened to him, I'd make sure you didn't go without.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be fine, Charlie. Half the people here owed Bumpy money when he died. A lot of money. If they think I'm going to forget to collect, they're wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the spirit. Go get them. On the TV, over archive film and photographs of crime figures from the 1940's and `50's, the opinion is offered that Bumpy's death "marks the end of an era ..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A figure, his back to us, walks slowly toward a blackboar like a man to the gallows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I live in fear of hearing my name called.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Roberts, Give us U.S. vs. Meade -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of walking up there, turning around, knowing every one of them knows more than I do -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Subject, issues, what the determination was and what it means to us today. Richie Roberts turns and faces his classmates, all of the decade or more younger than him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harlem's jagged teeth skyline juts across the river at th other end of the George Washington Bridge. On this side - sledgehammer gripped in Richie's fist, on the move, sudde fills the frame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know the Number 1 fear of most people isn't dying; it's public speaking. They get physically ill. They throw up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that's what you want to do for a living.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't like being like that.     I want to beat it. Armed with the sledgehammer, Richie and his partner - Jav Rivera - come past a seedy motel office where a TV shows another report about Bumpy Johnson. Legend:   New Jersey A motel clerk looks up, glimpses the sledgehammer -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey - Rivera flashes a New Jersey detective's shield without breaking stride. Takes a subpoena out of another pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's going to do this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He knows me, he'll take it from me. I've known him since high school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just throw it in, he doesn't take it. That's good service. They reach a particular motel room door. Rivera knocks. The door opens the length of a chain, revealing a wise gu in an undershirt, who, when he sees the subpoena, start t close the door -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Throw it - As Richie flings the subpoena in, the door slams on his hand. He wails in agony, tries to shoulder it open, hears the dead bolt lock on the other side, feels Campizi's tee bite into his fingers, watches his blood run down the fra

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Down - Richie hangs down from his hand as the sledgehammer swing past his head shattering the door -

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. MOTEL ROOM
dialogues.text: The door rips from its hinges and the detectives crash in The wise guy - Campizi - hurries for the bathroom, slams door. This one's hollow and the detectives more easily break through it - Campizi tries to climb out the bathroom window. Richie grabs him, throws him into the shower stall, taking the plastic curtain down with them, smearing it with blood as Richie beats at him before Rivera can pull him off.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: A male paramedic attends to Campizi's bloodied face while female paramedic cleans Richie's bloodied hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I swear to God, Richie, I didn't know it was you. I would never slam a door on your hand. Knowingly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You bit my fuckin hand -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richie lunges at him, hits him again with his injured han which hurts Richie more than it does Campizi. The paramedics manage to pull him away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What can we do, Richie? You don't want to do this. For old times sake, what can we do? Who do you want? Who can I give you? You want Big Sal's bookie? You want his accountant? I'll give him to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richie regards him a moment. A policy ring's accountant wouldn't be bad. He glances back to his paramedic dabbing at his bloody hand, and notices she's not bad-looking. Sh smiles back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four men in long black leather coats stride toward like they own the city. It's impossible to tell if they're cop or gangsters. Legend:   New York City

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of the same undercover cops - Detective Trupo - scribbles a signature and badge number different from the one on his gold shield lying next to the voucher requesti evidence needed in court. He pushes the voucher under a sign - "All Handguns and Narcotics Before 10am Next Window" - to a clerk who takes past floor-to-ceiling shelves covered with files, plastic bags bulging with handguns, knives and gambling receipts. Bulkier items - like shotguns and baseball bats - lie unwrapped with dangling tags. The clerk reaches a chain-link cage where the most valuab items are locked up - narcotics, pornography, cash - chec the voucher against tags, takes down an old green suitcas

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trupo's car - a Shelby Mustang - roars up. He climbs out, crosses to a warehouse with the suitcase as the other thr SIU Princes of the City follow from another car, cradling grocery bags.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trupo snaps the suitcase open revealing five half-kilo ba of uncut heroin in clear plastic bags. The other cops pul from the grocery bags: a Pyrex mixing bowl, flour sifter, boxes of milk-sugar, latex kitchen gloves, a medical scal and yellow baggies. Hands peel back the distinctive black and green "evidence tape on the clear plastic bags. Dump the heroin into twen yellow baggies. A half-kilo of lactose is poured into eac of the now-empty property room bags.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now just enough for the reagent test.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He removes one tablespoon of heroin from each of the baggies, and the now-almost-heroin-free powder is mixed through the flour sifter, poured back into the clear bags the tape resealed, the bags returned to the suitcase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The suitcase and   "heroin," and some weapons and money, been arranged on   an evidence table with the care of a M display window.    Trupo - the officer in charge of the c watches the jury   files in -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Lincoln Continental pulls up. Trupo climbs out of his Shelby with a sports bag, crosses to the Lincoln, climbs back where an Italian wise guy - Rossi - sits. Trupo unzi the bag revealing the recut heroin - in the yellow plasti

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the French Connection dope. The same dope Popeye Doyle and Sonny Grasso took from us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank comes into an empty bar, chairs up on tables. A middle-aged man mopping up glances up at him as he crosse to a back room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They seize it, arrest everybody, whack it up and sell it back to us. Our dope. They been living off it for years, these New York cops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Several ounces of the dope sits in foreground on a table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They basically control the market with it. What the fuck has happened to the world, Frank?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuckin crooks. Rossi, who looks more like a middle-aged accountant than Italian dope supplier he is, makes two espressos.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sad about Bumpy. Behind Frank, a TV airs a report by Walter Cronkite on th heroin problem among GIs in Vietnam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Things are never going to be the same in Harlem. The girls, the clubs, the music - walk down the street, nobody bothers you because Bumpy's making sure of it. (hands Frank one of the espressos)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How bad is it there now? 18pt   FLASHCUTS TO HARLEM Guys barge into a room, steal money from a crap game at gunpoint - Cops push guys against a bar, empty their pock - A dealer shoots another dealer in an alley - 18pt   BACK TO THE HOTEL ROOM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's chaos.    Every gorilla for himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 18pt   CONTINUED:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who can live like that? There has to be order. That would never happen with Italians. More important than any one man's life - is order.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A street sign on a corner:        116th and 8th Avenue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As is his custom, Frank eats breakfast alone. A middle- aged waitress appears when he's done, picks up his plate and refills his coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Charlene.      Last one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all right with me, Frank, you can stay all day if you want, but I wouldn't. It's nice outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then maybe I'll have to go for a walk. Just cause you said so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She smiles and leaves. Frank pours some sugar in his coffee. Someone taps on the window and he looks up, sees two servicemen - one in uniform - one he recognizes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank leads the servicemen up the stairs of a building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Corner apartment above the street. A girl sits smoking at a work table covered with drug-cutting apparatus. Another Frank's cutter and sometimes-girlfriend, Red Top - sets a couple of packets of heroin in front of the servicemen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the house for our men in uniform.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, thank you, sugar, that's very kind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank Frank.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Frank nods, you're welcome before the man can thank him. The servicemen start cooking up the dope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's Nate?   You seen him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All the time. Nate is everywhere. He's good. Got himself a club now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where, Saigon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bangkok.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think he's ever coming home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Regarding the dope as the servicemen shoot it up -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're gonna have to boot it a couple times. Cops keep cutting it, selling it, cutting it -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to say anything cause the price is right - but the shit in Nam is way, way, way, way, way -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He begins to nod out before he can finish the sentence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Across the river, Richie, Rivera and Campizi sit in the c parked across from a closed social club. A man carrying a grocery bag comes out and Campizi ducks lower in the seat

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Newsboy Moriarty's mob accountant puts the grocery bag in the trunk of a car, climbs in behind the wheel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From the parked car they observe the accountant putting another bag in his trunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He comes out of another place with another bag.       To

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right.   Get lost.    Get out. Campizi slinks out of the car. Richie and Rivera follow after Newsboy Moriarty's accountant's car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They tail the car into a lot, park and watch the accounta leave his car and get into another car that's parked ther RIVERA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We gonna stay with him or the car? Whatever they do, they'll have to decide quick. RICHIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's see who comes for the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All the other cars are gone. Rivera climbs into Richie's with coffee and a Coke in a bag, hands him the can. RIVERA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Think he made us? Richie doesn't know. Glances at his watch.      Cranes in seat to look behind them. RICHIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You called for the warrant?     Where are they? RIVERA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just called. I called and walked back here and ten seconds has gone by. Richie watches an attendant lock up, listens to the stree lamps buzz, grows impatient. Indicating the other car: RICHIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We saw him with the slips, Javy. RIVERA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You saw policy slips? You saw grocery bags. You don't know what's in them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I do, and so do you, don't give me that bullshit -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the rush? Half an hour the warrant'll be here -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got night school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guess you're going to miss it. (Rivera sips at his coffee;                            then:)                                                You know, what you were saying before - about throwing up in front of people - money will take that feeling away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not when it's less.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Less than what.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Than what I make now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No lawyer on earth makes less than a cop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They do in the Prosecutor's Office. Three thousand less.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're fuckin kidding me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richie isn't kidding. Rivera stares at him like he's craz Richie checks his watch. He's waited long enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck this -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richie -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richie gets out, opens the trunk, grabs a Slimjim and bolt cutters, cuts through a gate chain and strides to th accountant's car, Rivera following. Richie trips the passenger door lock and pulls at the trunk release, and, he comes around back to search it -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Check inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rivera may as well; the damage to the case, if there is o anymore, is done. He crawls inside the car to look under the seats and in the glove compartment. Gravely -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Javy ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richie's staring into the trunk like there's a body insid Rivera comes over, takes a look, sees it's money: stacks it rubber-banded together, spilling from grocery bags - m than either of them has ever seen. As the trunk closes -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richie and Rivera sit in their car in silence, staring ou at the car with the money in it. Eventually -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This isn't a couple of bucks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the same thing.   In principle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're talking about principle?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richie, a cop who turns in this kind of money says one thing: He'll turn in cops who take money. We'll be pariahs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're fucked either way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not if we keep it. Only if we don't. Then we're fucked, you're right. But not if we keep it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (more to himself) Yes, we are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goddamn it, did we ask for this? Did we put a gun to someone's head and say, Give us your money? Cops kill cops they can't                  trust. We can't turn it in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They regard each other again in silence ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As a police captain counts the stacks of money, Lou Tobac Richie's superior from the prosecutors office, walks in, night out interrupted by this emergency. He crossed to wh Richie and Rivera sit alone in a corner. Quietly: TOBACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much. RICHIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nine hundred and eighty thousand. TOBACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened to the rest? It's a joke but isn't funny, not even to Toback. He regar his men who turned it in, then the other cops in the plac who are watching them and the money being counted. Toback walks over to the captain, and, quietly: TOBACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What're you doing counting this in front of everybody? Are you out of your fuckin mind? Take it into a room. Now. Richie's glance to Rivera says, You're right, we're fucke

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. NEWARK POLICE STATION
dialogues.text: As Richie leaves alone, he's aware of all the eyes on him knowing the other cops' looks don't signify awe or respec but contempt and fear, like Rivera predicted. Neither wil ever be trusted again. He climbs into his car, drives off

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tango and his bodyguard come in and approach Frank's tabl where he reads the morning paper as he eats breakfast. TANGO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't you see the jar, Frank? I think you walked right past it. Frank ignores him, forks at his eggs, eats.    Tango sits TANGO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The money jar. On the corner.      What I got to do, put a sign on it? Frank indicates that he would answer if his mouth wasn't full. He swallows finally, but then only reaches for his coffee cup to take a sip, further irritating Tango.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bumpy don't own 116th Street no more, Frank. Bumpy don't own no real estate in Harlem no more. I'm the landlord now and the lease is twenty-percent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank dabs at his mouth with a napkin and gives Tango a l that says that won't be happening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then don't sell dope, Frank. Get a fuckin job. You need a job? You can be my driver, drive me around, open my door, yes, sir, no sir, where to, sir, right away, Massa Johnson, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right now Tango is dead. No doubt about it.          On t surface, though, Frank remains cool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty percent?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of every dollar. Every VIG, every truckload, every girl, every ounce.      In the jar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty percent's my profit. If I'm giving it to you then what am I doing? Twenty percent puts me, and everyone you know, out of business, which puts you out of business. (reaches for his breakfast check) There are ways to make money legitimately, and then there's this way. Not even Bumpy took twenty percent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bumpy's fuckin dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank regards Tango a moment, gets up, takes out his mone clip, covers the check on the table with a five, peels of $1 bill from the clip, tosses it down in front of Tango.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There.   That's twenty-percent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he turns and leaves, Tango watches after him ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stitched-up, black and blue hands dump a can of soup in a pot, put it on the stove.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pencil clutched by long fingers scribbles figures. But no matter how many times Frank does the arithmetic, there not much left, he calculates, after he pays the Italian suppliers and, if he were to, Tango.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richie has moved to a small desk cluttered with law textbooks. He cracks one open to study for the New Jersey Bar exam as he eats the soup out of the pot he heated it Above him on the wall is a framed photograph of Joe Louis standing over a sprawled-on-the-mat Billy Conn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bleak day. Seagulls fighting over scraps on the sand as others hover overhead, flapping and cawing. Alone near th water, Frank tosses a stick for the German shepherd he inherited.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richie opens a small wooden box in his bleak apartment, revealing an ounce of marijuana, rolling papers and clips As he rolls a joint - BUMPY V/O

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A leader is like a shepherd -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sounds of the gulls and surf and roller coaster begin fade as Frank throws the stick again. BUMPY V/O

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sends the fast nimble sheep out front, and the others follow as the shepherd walks quietly behind - The dog retrieves the stick, but this time - somehow - it to Bumpy's hand he returns it. Frank listens attentively. BUMPY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's got the stick - the cane - and he'll use if he has to. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But most of the time he doesn't have to. He moves the whole herd - quietly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bumpy smiles and tosses the stick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The smoke from the joint rises to the ceiling as Richie studies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dog trots back to Bumpy and Frank with the stick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hot dog stand. Bumpy hands a hot dog to Frank, holds out another to the shepherd. To camera:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What right do they have cutting out the suppliers, the middlemen, buying direct, putting Americans out of work ... This is the way it is now, Frank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank nods. The vender hands him a napkin. The shepherd is still with him, but Bumpy is gone, and the gulls and t people on the roller coaster squeal as Frank comes out of his meditative trance with an idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A needle pierces the crook of Frank's arm.       Slight g A cotton ball is pushed onto the puncture.       Malaria

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A strobe lights up Frank's face:      a passport photo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The photo and a duplicate are stapled to a passport application.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keys turn the locks of a safety-deposit box. The lid lift revealing decks of cash. Frank takes it all out, slips on slender packet into Bumpy's banker's jacket pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get yourself a new suit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Under portraits of bank Vice Presidents before him, the m types out a Chemical Bank check for Frank for $400,000.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sound of the plane growls and fades overhead as Richi ex-wife keeps an eye on their son playing on a grassy are

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, Richie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It couldn't be avoided. Next weekend I'll be able to take him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She regards him with a weary look, but he's looking over one of the other - better-looking - moms in the park.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm moving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks back, not sure he heard right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?   Where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To the St. Regis, what do you care. (pause) My sister's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your sister's. In Vegas?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He glances away to a sound: shattering glass.        Some agers breaking bottles on the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't move to Vegas.     Not with Michael anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What am I supposed to do with him?       Leave him with you? There's a picture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the vandals) Hey, you want to shut up over there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The teenagers ignore him. He tries to ignore them, but it hard with the constant noise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No court will allow it for one thing. I won't allow it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When am I supposed to see my son?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Last weekend!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Their son glances over at them. Richie looks over at the teenagers again breaking bottles, then back to Laurie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laurie, you can't raise a kid in Las Vegas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, like this is a good environment. Around your friends. There are less creeps in Vegas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's he going to grow up to be in a mobbed up place like that? What are you thinking?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm thinking - Richie - of him!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goddamn it -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The noise of the glass is driving him crazy. He strides over to the teenagers, who look at him like, What are you gonna do, old man, it's four against one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you nice to shut the fuck up. Now I'm gonna kill you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pulls out his gun and aims it at one of them, then the others. All instinctively try to cover their heads.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pick up the fuckin glass!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they dive to their knees to do what they're told, Laur walks away with her son, who looks back over his shoulder his father with his gun out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank sits in the back of a motor samlor.       Bicycles around it like flies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The clientele is almost exclusively black servicemen on R and Asian women. A trio of ex-GI's plays authentic Southe blues on a small stage. Ham hocks and collard greens come out of the kitchen. Smoke chokes the place. Frank, one of the few men not in uniform, and not drunk o stoned, sits alone at a table with a Coca-Cola and survey the activity: Dope being rolled. Dope being smoked. Dope being shot. GI's and prostitutes climbing a staircase. His eyes follow an Army Master Sergeant, moving among the tables as if checking on the GI's well being. But at some his hand takes money, leaves in its place packets of powd The Sergeant feels eyes on him and glances up, catching Frank watching him from across the room. He squints throu the smoke at the figure at the table in the shadows, and, a kind of shock, more to himself -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank - ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank half-lifts his glass to wave, and Nate beams.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank has guests at his table now: his cousin Nate the Sergeant, and two young Asian wise guys. They talk about him in Thai (subtitled):

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He say how much he wants?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He said "a lot." What that means, I don't know. Four or five keys?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The Thais regard Frank a moment, size him up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's your cousin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My cousin-in-law.    My ex-wife's cousin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ask him how much he wants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much you gonna want, Frank?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hundred kilos.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nate blinks like there's something in his eye ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steam and neon.    Frank and Nate at a crowded stand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one I know can get that much. It'd have to be pieced together from several suppliers and none of it's gonna be 100- percent pure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not what I want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know that. But that means dealing with the Chiu-Chou syndicates in Cholon or Saigon - if they'll deal with you -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, even then it's too late. It's been chopped. I want to get it where they get it. From the source.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nate stares at him ... then laughs.       Frank doesn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're gonna go get it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're gonna go into the fuckin jungle -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've lived in jungles all my (life) -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. This is the jungle. Tigers. Vietcong. The fuckin snakes alone will kill you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A room of student-type desks and no character. Richie, and fifty others, have been here for hours taking the exa less than half of them will pass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A motley bunch of Thai thugs and black American soldiers with automatic weapons ride mules through the dense jungl with Nate and Frank, who - armed with a pistol, a rifle a ammo bandolier like Pancho Villa - is enjoying himself. From his POV, the jungle canopy suddenly opens up on a po field the size of Manhattan. Frank stares down at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the ground now with their small private army, Nate spe with one of the Thais, then translates for Frank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He says this whole area's controlled by the Kuomintang - Chiang Kai-Shek's defeated army.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some of whom they can see down below on the opium farm - Chinese soldiers with outdated weapons. Frank tips his he to Nate at some other figures below -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They ain't Chinese.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A handful of better-armed American sentries at the perime of the farm. CIA. Frank, Nate and the others hang back as one of the Thais steps ahead to speak to the guerillas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The processing center for the entire region. The Thai translator is with Frank to negotiate with a vanquished Chinese general. Other Americans and Thais guard them while the Chinese with their CIA advisors guard them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Chinese general examines Frank's papers - passport, visa, bank receipts - and lots of cash - then studies Fra

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How would you get it into the States?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you care?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who do you work for in there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you care?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are you really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It says right there.   Frank Lucas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, who you represent?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me. The man doesn't believe it, but lets it go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think you're going to take a hundred kilos of heroin into the US and you don't work for anyone? Someone is going to allow that? Frank shrugs. The general regards one of his men.       I Chinese, subtitled:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't believe a word of this. The general regards the cash and paperwork again for a moment. And, to Frank:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After this first purchase, if you're not killed by Marseilles importers - or their people in the States - then what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then there'd be more. On a regular basis. Though I'd rather not have to drag my ass all the way up here every time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man regards Frank for a long moment.       Glances ba the cash and paperwork again. Finally -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Torrential monsoon rains. Dripping camouflage. Nate and Frank climb down from the Huey. Frank no longer wears the bandolier. Now a press card dangles from his neck.

dialogues.speaker: F56 INT/EXT. TENT / JUNGLE ARMY LZ
dialogues.text: Stripes on the uniform of a black colonel with Nate under canopy. Outside, in the distance, in the rain, Frank hang out with some other black servicemen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's it now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bangkok. I can bring it here or anywhere in between.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hundred kilos. (Nate nods) I never seen that much dope in one place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's bigger than an Amana refrigerator- freezer.

dialogues.speaker: G56 INT/EXT. JUNGLE ARMY LZ
dialogues.text: Nate and Frank watch the colonel emerge from the tent and cross through the rain on duck-boards to another tent to speak with a white officer, a 2-star general.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fifty grand. In advance. That'll cover them, the pilots and the guys on the other end.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give them a hundred.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fifty, to cover them all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hundred. And it's all I got left. So if that dope doesn't arrive, for whatever reason - (embraces Nate and whispers) Cousin or no cousin - don't let me down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He holds out a business envelope fat with money. Nate hesitates, knowing Frank has just said he'll kill him if things don't go right, then takes it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll let you know when it's in the air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The nurse/paramedic who stitched up his hand is in Richie bed making so much noise he's worried someone will call t cops. The phone rings. And won't stop. Neither will the nurse as Richie answers it -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richie? Richie, I'm in trouble.    This fuckin guy "made" me - I don't know how but he did. He went for his gun. I had to do it, I swear to God. Now they're going to kill me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richie can hear in Sander's voice how serious it is and manages to disentangle himself from the woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a hundred people out there heard the shots. You gotta help me. You gotta do something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is he dead?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's dead.    I'm dead. They're gonna kill me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you? Javy, where are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the problem.

dialogues.speaker: EARLY MORNING
dialogues.text: Richie on his police radio, which cuts in and out -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are no cars in that area, Detective Roberts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bullshit. I got a man in trouble and I need back-up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I missed that - you're breaking up -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said, put the fucking call out again -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just did. No one responded.     I'll try again, but -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck you, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He slams the mic down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Richie's car turns a corner, the Stephen Crane Project the most foreboding place on earth - rises up: three dark 30-floor towers planted on war-torn grounds where a long- torched and abandoned patrol car sits like a monument. He parks and moves through an agitated all-black crowd, p an ambulance outside one of the towers, through oppressiv heat. It's riot weather.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drugs on a coffee table. Body on the floor. Rivera, despondent, on the couch. The male paramedics, scared. Richie on the phone -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sergeant, I'm not asking, I'm fuckin telling you: Get some patrolmen over here now.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Dial tone: the police sergeant has hung up on him. throws the phone. The paramedics stare at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got no back-up? Why is that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The only other person who would know the answer to that i Rivera, who just shakes his head in despair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bandage his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Detective ... he's dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know he's fucking dead. Bandage his head, clean him up, put him on a gurney and prop it up so he's sitting. And open his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richie comes out ahead of the gurney, moving quickly like it's a matter of life and death (which it is), motioning the crowd to allow a path to the ambulance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Step back, injured man coming out. Let them do their job and he'll be all right. Ma'am. Excuse me. Step back. Sir. Please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The people step back when they see the victim on the gurn tubes in his nostrils, IV in his arm, eyes open. Before t can look any closer, he's put in the ambulance. As it pul out, siren wailing, Richie leads Rivera safely away -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They cross through an alley near the Projects and Rivera finally breathes a sigh of relief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The words aren't out of his mouth before Richie shoves hi up against a car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You robbed him, didn't you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?   What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richie rips Rivera's jacket pockets.        Money spills

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This.   Where'd this come from?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What. That's my money. I've never taken dirty money in my life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You lying piece of shit -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe the occasional gratuity. Like anybody else. You're going to tell me that's wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it isn't. It's part of the salary for getting shot at. For that, certain courtesies are shown. In gratitude -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richie, disgusted with him, lets go of him.         River embarrassed, almost crying, pleading -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A discount on a TV, a Doughboy in the backyard, a new dress for your girlfriend maybe once a year. I'm talking about not living in fucking poverty. You want to call that wrong, call it wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then goddamn it, pay me fifty grand a year, you son of a bitch. Pay me what I deserve for getting shot at. No? Fine. Next time four guys come into your place with sawed-off shotguns, you take care of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You robbed him, and then you shot him, and I helped you get out of there. How many more you shot?

dialogues.speaker: A60 CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Rivera suddenly tries to get tough -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what, Richie? Fuck you, you make that kind of accusation against your own kind. And you know why.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes out his car keys, turns to leave. Comes past Richie who grabs his arm and pushes the sleeve up exposin line of puncture scabs and scars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a disgrace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a leper. Because I listened to you and turned in a million fucking dollars. You know who'll work with me after that? Same as you. No one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richie squeezes Rivera's hand around the car key.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't look down there. Look here. (at Richie's eyes) You ever fuckin threaten me again, I'll kill you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richie squeezes Sander's hand so hard the car key cuts through the skin, drawing blood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence. Marshland. A beat-up Chevy parked alongside a perimeter fence. Frank waits by the car as a military Jee with its lights out comes across a firing range. It slows stops. In it, the silhouettes of three servicemen, black, armed with M-16's. Silence again, before:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Open the trunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank does it, then stands aside as the other servicemen drag four large taped-up duffel bags from the Jeep to his car, lift them into his trunk and slam it shut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The duffel bags, still closed, on a table. Frank regards them, nursing a drink, putting off the moment of discover that he has perhaps spent his life's savings on nothing.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The German shepherd watches as Frank removes the tape fro one of the bags. He pulls it open - has almost no reactio except to breathe again - then opens the next, and the ne And we see: Several brick-like packages of No. 4 heroin wrapped in paper marked with Chinese writing, stamped wit a label: two lions on their hind legs, paws on a globe, and, in English: DOUBLE UOGLOBE BRAND 100%.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The duffel bags are elsewhere. The only evidence of any drugs is the small amount Frank has given a chemist - who looks like a Harvard student - to test. It responds instantly. The young man looks at Frank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Typically what I see is 25 to 45 percent pure. I've never seen anything like this. No alkaloids, no adulterants, no dilutents. It's a hundred percent. May I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The chemist opens a leather travel syringe kit to shoot u but Frank gives him some to take home instead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take it with you. I don't want to have to call the coroner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The chemist gathers his things to leave, offering a last piece of advice -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Store it in a cool, dark place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A clapboard house set down on a piece of land that was probably once worked by sharecroppers. An elderly woman framed in a lit kitchen window, doing dishes. Dark yew trees and scavenged, discarded cars and car part like patches of rusty snow. Crickets and bullfrogs. From mound of dirt, a young man hurls a baseball to another wi a catcher's mitt exactly sixty feet away. The kid's got a major league arm. Legend:   Greensboro, North Carolina A glow spills out from a detached shed where a short man his early 30's works on a stock car.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: A greasy phone on the workbench rings and another disreputable-looking man, thumbing through a magazine, answers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah ... for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmy doesn't know, sets it down. Teddy comes over wiping his hands on a rag, takes the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Teddy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank your brother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Divorced couples in custody battles wait with their attorneys in a packed courthouse. An lawyer carrying pape clipped with a $10 bill, comes past Richie, who's sitting with his lawyer, a woman he's probably slept with.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not talking about your proclivities, Richie. Those I only know too well. I'm talking about being a cop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About taking money? I don't care about money. I don't do that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because it'll come out. You're going to have to sit down with shrinks and social workers, her lawyers, the judge, lots of questions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's going on there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The judge's assistant rearranging the pre-trial cases in order of the amount of gratuity clipped to each - $5, $10 $20 bills.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scheduling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, the money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scheduling. What about your friends from the neighborhood? You still hang out with them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I play softball on Sundays with some guys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wise guys.    That's going to look good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I grew up with them, big deal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about Anthony Zaca?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richie, I'm just trying to understand things your wife has said. If they're not true, tell me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, Tony's one of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is he also your son's godfather?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richie nods. Sheila glances over to where Richie's ex-wif sits with her own lawyer across the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you really care about this? Or do you just not want her to win - ever. How often do you see your son as it is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not enough.   But she wants to make it never.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, all right. Give me a twenty. (Richie doesn't reach for                              his wallet)                                           Well, I'm not going to sit here all day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She takes a twenty from her purse and carries it up to th judge's assistant clipped to their paperwork.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All rise -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank and the dog in the back yard of a suburban house. His neighbors - those he can see - are white. He hears a sound - cars arriving - and crosses toward the house wher a sold "For Sale" sign leans against a half-built kennel. Out front, a caravan of cars and pickup trucks - North Carolina plates - loaded with boxes and suitcases - has j arrived. Exhausted from the drive but excited to be here, the travelers climb out: Frank's five brothers, their wiv and kids, and their mother. Teddy thinks it's the right place. The others aren't as sure. The house is too nice. There's a new Lincoln Townca parked outside the garage. They'll probably be shot for trespassing. The front door opens and Frank comes out, trailed by his dog. He first gathers his mother in an embrace, then each of his startled brothers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The house is alive with the noise of family and scent of home-cooked food as the extended Lucas clan - there's mor than twenty of them - sits around a big dining room table passing the platters around. Frank, at the head of the table, clearly loves having them all here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He got an arm on him.     Major League arm, ain't that right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone agrees as Turner's son - Frank's nephew - the 18 year-old boy seen pitching in the North Carolina back yar tries to shrug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You show me after supper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't catch him. He'll take your head off. We're talking 95-mile-an-hour. You know how fast that is? You see the ball leave his hand, and that's the last you see it before it knocks you down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling; happy) Is that right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The wonderful noise continues downstairs as Frank leads h mother on a tour of the upstairs. The place is a showroom of traditional Americana.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is your room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Lucas is   in awe of the splendor of the bedroom and furnishings.    It's unlike anything she's used ever seen not Graceland   exactly - but not far off. Her eyes settl an old vanity   dotted with French perfume bottles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did you ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had it made. From memory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were five when they took it away. How could you remember it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I remember.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's stunned. Touches the reproduction of the vanity her son last saw more than thirty years ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's perfect. (looks at the room) It's all perfect. (she looks at him) I'm so proud of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Statue of Liberty against the New York skyline. FRANK V/O

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man I worked for ran one of the biggest companies in New York City for almost fifty years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Frank leads his brothers down the sidewalk, the Townca that was parked at the Teaneck house, driven by Frank's b guard, Doc, follows alongside at the same pace they walk. FRANK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was with him every day for fifteen of them, looking after him, taking care of things, protecting him, learning from him. The brothers can't help but notice the storekeepers who w to Frank, the women who smile, the men who step out of hi path like there's a red carpet under his polished shoes. FRANK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bumpy was rich, but never white   man rich. Why? Because he didn't own the    company. He thought he did. He didn't.     He only managed it. Someone else owned    it. So they owned him.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. REDTOP'S APARTMENT BUILDING
dialogues.text: Frank leads his brothers up the stairs and down the hall. FRANK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody owns me. Because I own my company. INTERCUT: Feminine hands stamp small packets of blue cellophane with the words `Blue Magic' - FRANK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And my company sells a product that's better than the competition's at a price that's lower. Frank stops outside an apartment door. TEDDY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are we selling, Frank?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Frank pushes the door open, revealing -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five naked women at work tables, their faces veiled by surgical masks, cutting heroin with lactose and quinine i precise mixture of controlled purity. The Lucas brothers stare as the supervisor of the activity - clothed, with r hair - comes over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Frank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey, these are my brothers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tango strolls down the street like he's the Godfather of Harlem, girl on his arm, bodyguard at his side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As his brothers eat lunch, Frank - who can see Tango outs - uncaps a glass sugar container.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What matters in business is honesty, integrity, hard work, loyalty, and never forgetting where you came from.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For reasons his brothers can't imagine, Frank empties all sugar from the container onto his plate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are what you are and that's one of two things. You're nothing ... or you're something. Understand what I'm saying?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The brothers nod tentatively, stare at the now-empty glas container. Frank wipes his mouth with a napkin, gets up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be right back.

dialogues.speaker: EXT/INT. DINER
dialogues.text: He comes out of the diner, crosses the street toward Tang who's buying fruit. Greets him cheerfully -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Tango, what's up.    I was just thinking about you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was looking at the jar and you know what? I didn't    see nothing in it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The fuck you want, Frank -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before the last word is out of Tango's mouth, Frank's got gun pressed against his forehead. Silence. Everyone backs away - the bodyguard, too. Tango's girl pulls her arm fro his and takes off. Eventually -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What're you going to do, boy? Shoot me in broad daylight? In front of everyone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's as if life on the street has stopped. No one moves; everyone is looking at Frank; maybe that's what he wants. As Tango laughs at the thought -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, that's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank pulls the trigger and the big man falls back like someone hit with a board. Frank stands over him and empti the gun in his chest, the shots echoing down the street. Then it's quiet again. Everyone's still looking him, but Frank doesn't run. Instead, he calmly reaches into Tango' suit pocket, takes out a money clip thick with cash, drop it in the "jar" and sets it next to the body.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For the cops. Should be enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank returns to the diner and sits back down, ignoring t astonished stares from his brothers and everyone else in place. Tries to remember where he was in his lecture as h tucks the napkin back in his shirt collar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That basically's the whole picture right there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cadaver drawer slides open revealing - not Tango - but Rivera, staring up lifeless, his arms, stomach, legs and toes dotted with the scabs of a longtime addict.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you know his girlfriend? Good- looking girl. One of his informants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The medical examiner slides open another cadaver drawer containing her body. Richie stares at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Should've seen their place.    Like animals lived there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have seen it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the examiner) Chose a good night, huh?   Grand Central Station in here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's been like this. I'm lucky I get home before midnight; lots of careless- ness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richie regards Rivera's personal effects resting on his chest in a plastic bag: few bucks, the Corvette key, a ha empty packet of heroin in blue cellophane. Richie takes t blue cellophane from the bag and, as the drawer closes entombing Sanders, holds it in his hand ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heroin addiction is no longer exclusive to big city neighborhoods; it's epidemic -

dialogues.speaker: TIME CUT. A TELEVISION
dialogues.text: The reports shows lawmakers on Capitol Hill juxtaposed against images of inner-cities, junkies, homicide victims and, perhaps most telling, white suburbia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Since 1965, law enforcement has watched its steady increase and with it a rise in violent crime. Now unaccountably, it has exploded, reaching into cities as a whole - our suburbs and towns - our schools.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The TV is in a small police gym where Richie lifts weight very much aware of his pariah status as out-of-shape cops come in, only to leave again when they see him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone is finally saying: enough. Federal authorities have announced their intention to establish special narcotics bureaus in Washington, New York, Los Angeles, Chicago, Boston, Newark and other major cities -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toback comes in, watches Richie, alone, working out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a dog and pony show.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not being advertised as one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richie's changing into his street clothes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it's federal. I'd have to answer to who? FBI?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me and the U.S. Attorney. No one else. No FBI. Hoover knows better than to mix his men with dope. Too much temptation for the feeble-minded.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Though he's not in much of a position to refuse the assignment, Richie still isn't convinced it's a good idea Toback levels with him -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richie, a detective who doesn't have the cooperation of his fellow detectives can't be effective.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know why I don't have it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doesn't matter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, they're all on the take and I'm not and it doesn't matter to anyone. Instead of giving you a medal for turning in money, they bury you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's fucked up. You're right. Maybe this's an opportunity away from all that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They regard each other.    Eventually -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll do it, but only like this: I don't set foot in a police station again. I work out of a place of my own. And I pick my own guys. Guys I know wouldn't take a nickel off the sidewalk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An old building that was once an Episcopal church.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The place has been long abandoned. The city maintenance worker who let Richie in watches him move through the deb strewn church.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A real estate broker watches Frank consider the high- ceilinged spaciousness of a grand, unfurnished 50's moder Upper East Side penthouse -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richie regards the colored light thrown down by the stain glass windows -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank regards light streaming in from the garden terrace

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richie picks up a faded photograph of a priest in a broke frame. To the maintenance man:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the only floor we'll be using.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank distractedly opens and closes a 12' high curtain in one of the rooms -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No loan, no contingencies.    Cash sale.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wet streets and neon. Well-dressed crowd behind a velvet rope outside the club. The Apollo in the background: Jame Brown on the marquee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A still-powerful older man in a nice suit rises from his chair to wild applause. From the stage -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Joe Louis, ladies and gentlemen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe bows graciously, gives a little wave to the crowd, an sits back down as the band starts up again. At another table, Frank sits with Charlie Williams and Rossi, slightly older dope men. Like Frank, they favor expensive tailored suits. Their dates, too, are nicely dressed - not too much make-up or jewelry. Frank's glance moves from Joe Louis and his wife to a beautiful young wo at the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's the beauty queen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is a beauty queen.    No kidding. Miss Puerto Rico.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her glance crosses Frank's briefly but is yanked to the entrance of the club when Frank's brothers come in with their wives and girlfriends. Teddy's in a parrot green suit, gold chains, hat, acting like he owns the place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank hustles Teddy into an empty back room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns Teddy so he's facing a mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What. These are clothes.     This is a very nice (suit) -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm wearing clothes. These are clothes. Those - (Teddy's in the mirror) - are a costume. With a sign on it that says Arrest me. You look like fuckin Jackie Fox.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong with Jackie.    I like Jackie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You like Jackie? You want to be Superfly? Go work for him, end up in a cell with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Teddy pulls himself from Frank's grasp. Smooths his shirt adjusts his hat. Frank tries to explain to him:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guy making all the noise in the room is the weak one. That's not who you want to be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wants to talk to you by the way.     I told him I'd tell you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank stares at his brother's reflection in the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You and Jackie were talking about me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not about you. We were talking. He said he wanted to talk to you about something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank clearly wants nothing to do with Jackie Fox.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm taking you shopping tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I went shopping today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You go shopping every day.    Like a girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A creme Bentley pulls up and out pour Jackie Fox and his entourage.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He's got an armful of New York Times Magazines -with him the cover, flaunting Gangster Chic. He starts handing the out to the crowd on his way into the club.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe Louis has come over to speak to Frank at his table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a tax thing. It's a mistake my lawyers will straighten out, but for the time being it's a headache -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much you owe?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's nothing, like - fifty grand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank isn't sure if it's an honor or a curse to have a celebrity like Joe Louis asking to borrow money, but nods

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.   Don't worry about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.   I'll pay you back soon as -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe. It's a gift. Not a loan.       You don't owe me nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie glides into the club with his magazines and entourage. Frank watches him make the rounds, lingering a Miss Puerto Rico's table and holding her hand longer than should with his girlfriend on his arm. Frank glances to Teddy wearily, then to Doc, alone at the next table like sentry. Frank doesn't have to say he's ready to leave. Do knows the look. Gets up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank comes into the coat check area where Doc waits with his overcoat. As Frank slips into it, Miss Puerto Rico - returning from the ladies room - comes through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi.   I'm Ana.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Frank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're Frank and this is your place. (he doesn't say whether it is or not) Why's it called Small's? Why don't you call it Frank's?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I don't have to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He smiles, and it's hard to tell which is more enchanted with the other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A club across the river. Not nearly as nice as Small's - much louder - but like Small's, almost all black. Richie shares a booth with a black undercover detective.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm reluctant to bring anyone in I don't personally know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know me, and I vouch for them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richie nods, Yeah, he knows that, but remains unconvinced

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richie, we work together. You want me, you got to take them, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spearman looks out across the crowded dance floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's Jones. With the skinny white woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richie's glance finds a young black man dancing wildly wi his skinny white date.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's Abruzzo, with the fat black one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richie sees a young Italian with tatoos - the only other white man in the place - dancing with a heavy black woman Both Jones and Abruzzo look more like criminals than cops

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Both are good with wires. Have good informants. They're honest. And they're fearless. They'll do anything. They're insane, Richie, like you.

dialogues.speaker: NEW YORK
dialogues.text: Frank sits in back alone. Peers ahead through the windshield. His face relaxes as he sees -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ana waiting on a corner, dressed nice, handbag.         T pulls to the curb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank gets out before Doc can, and escorts Ana to the car

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope you weren't waiting long. A woman as beautiful as you shouldn't have to wait for anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He opens the door for her like a perfect gentleman, slide in after her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Outside the house, Doc sits in the car reading a newspape

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ana considers some family photographs on a mantle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is your father?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank shakes his head no.       It's a picture of Bumpy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You really don't know who that is? (she doesn't) It's Martin Luther King.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're right. He was as important as Dr. King, though.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'd he do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lot of things. He had a lot of friends. He served New York and it served him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was he to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank has to think.     Bumpy was more than his employer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Teacher.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'd he teach you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How to take my time ... how if you're going to do something, do it with care ... do it with love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And it's working here.     It's seductive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anything else?

dialogues.speaker: FLASHCUTS -
dialogues.text: Sudden bursts of violence - guys beat up - others shot - being poured with gasoline as Bumpy looks on calmly -

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO FRANK'S LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: The same calm, benign face in the photograph.        Fran

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How be a gentleman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what you are?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ana smiles like she knows better. Any second now, like every other guy she's ever met, she's sure he'll try to t her upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got five different apartments in the city I could've taken you to. I brought you here instead -

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Ana glances to the stairs which Frank's mother is coming down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To meet my mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this her? Oh, she's beautiful, Frank. Look at her. She's an angel come down from heaven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Lucas embraces Ana like family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A single, half-empty packet of heroin, the same one from morgue, in distinctive blue cellophane, tacked to a bulle board. Richie, perched on a desk in front of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our mandate is to make major arrests. No street guys - we want the suppliers - the distributors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spearman, Jones and Abruzzo sit in the back, looking like delinquent students. Of everyone in the open ground-floor that's been only slightly renovated - and there are about fifteen of them - they're the most disreputable-looking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heroin, cocaine, amphetamines. No grass under a thousand pounds. Less than that, someone else can waste their time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jones nudges Abruzzo to pay attention. Abruzzo elbows him back. Richie just waits like a teacher for their attentio

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll be handling big shipments, big money, big temptation. (Jones raises his hand) Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a story about you. About turning in some money. A lot of money. Is it true?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jones isn't the only one here curious to know.        Sim

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not true.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. CAR / STREET
dialogues.text: Abruzzo, looking like a junkie, dirty jeans, wool cap, approaches a dealer on the corner. The perspective shifts to Richie, Spearman and Jones in a car, watching as Abruz chats briefly with the dealer before the exchange takes place: $10 for a blue-cellophane packet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richie and the others watch Jones tests the heroin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stuff's ten percent pure. Strong enough to smoke for all those suburban white kids afraid of needles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The other detectives are exchange a glance.       None ha heard of anything on the street that pure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You paid ten bucks for it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And it's all that's out there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, how is that possible? Who can afford to sell shit twice as good for half as much?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richie glances to a Table of Organization: Surveillance photos haphazardly thumb-tacked to a bulletin board - kno dope men in the hierarchies of their individual crime families - almost all of them Italian.

dialogues.speaker: WOMB TO TOMB SEQUENCE
