dialogues.text: An R & B song begins and continues over -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A poppy bulb being pierced, the white liquid oozing, changing into filthy liquids in wooden bowls, and finally a gray paste ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank sits with the bank Vice President who wires a trans to:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where Nate sits with the same Thai bank president as befo who converts the transfer to cash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nate slides cash across a table to a couple of Chinese gangsters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tent: Nate hands more cash - the military brass's cut - to the 2-star general from before. An airstrip: Slicing propellers. Wounded soldiers on stretchers, helped onto a transport plane. Nearby, four large crates - Japanese TVs - under cargo netting. The pilot stuffs more cash in a pouch and salutes Nate.

dialogues.speaker: TV IMAGE
dialogues.text: General Westmoreland returns a salute (archive).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The same plane on the tarmac here, taxiing. A pile of discarded TV boxes outside a supply warehouse. At the perimeter of the base, black servicemen transfer heavy taped-up duffel bags from an Army Jeep to a station wagon, hoisting those that won't fit inside onto a roof rack. Two Lucas brothers tie them down with twine.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. CAR / HIGHWAY
dialogues.text: The station wagon heading north on a rain-slicked highway the canvas tarpaulin on top flapping. In the distance, th spire of the Washington monument glows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A black woman pushes a shopping cart containing a baby, Pampers, and cases of milk sugar across a parking lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Empty milk sugar boxes. Redtop and her five table workers - clothed now, the surgical masks dangling from their nec wiping down table surfaces, scales and apparatus. Tens of thousands of blue-cellophane packets of heroin neatly cov two of the folding tables.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: August. Hot. Kids wrench open a fire hydrant and with an empty soda can direct the water into a fountain. The wate sprays down onto the windshield of a beat-up Chevy coming slowly through, revealing when it clears, Frank behind th wheel. He parks. Glances at his watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clock on the wall of a locker area: 3:58. Shift change. Cops in t-shirts. Fans blowing the humid air around.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. NYPD 23RD PRECINCT GARAGE
dialogues.text: Blue and whites arriving and leaving, shirts coming off a the cops alight.

dialogues.speaker: 116TH STREET
dialogues.text: The driver checks his watch:   3:59.   Turns his almost-e bus up 8th Avenue.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. FRANK'S PARKED CHEVY
dialogues.text: Air conditioner full blast. Radio announcing the time: 4 o'clock. Frank glances out the wet windshield of the Chev and watches 116th Street transform: It's as if an outdoor market has just opened its stalls. Junkies and dealers emerging from the alleys, storefronts tenements and side streets - from the street itself it se - snarling the cars and delivery trucks caught unaware. Small blue cellophane packets - and only blue - are pulle from pockets and change hands. In alleyways it's cooked u and sucked into syringes, and in dank, grim, indescribabl filthy rooms, plunged into veins -

dialogues.speaker: AND THE REVERSE
dialogues.text: 10 and 20 dollar bills changing hands - decks of cash rubber-banded together - put into envelopes and delivered to the Lucas brothers, to: 125   LESTER at his metal door shop. 126   EUGENE at his dry cleaners. 127   TURNER at his tire service shop. 128   EARL at his electrical shop.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 129   TEDDY at his body shop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Piles of cash.    The brothers try counting it all, but i just too much.    It's actually tiring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're going to be here all night if we count every bill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIME CUT: A money-counting machine flips through the bills, its counter flying. The brothers rubberband it all in $100,000 decks. Jot down the numbers. Put the money in newly-assembled file boxes. Tape them shut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alone in the room, Frank transfers stacks of $100's from file boxes into several open safety-deposit boxes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The penthouse is now richly decorated. The R & B musi playing through a state-of-the-art stereo system. It's a kind of office party for Frank's brothers, cousins, wives and girlfriends, distributors like Rossi and other East Harlem guys, Charlie Williams, couple of cops on Frank's payroll, and the Chemical Bank Vice President.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got a stockbroker, Frank?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I deal with enough crooks as it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The banker jots down a name and phone number on the back one of his business cards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This one couldn't be more honest. Ask around. He's got a lot of clients in the business. You can't leave all your money in safety deposit boxes; give him a call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The banker hands him the card and moves on. Frank's tryin to have a good time, but the level of noise and revelry i beginning to make him uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank.   This is Mike Sibota.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sibota tries not to look as nervous as he feels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Sibota.   What can I get you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A left-hander from what Charlie tells me. Your nephew?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank points to his nephew, Stevie, across the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's been his dream all his life to play for the Yankees - and he's good enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So I hear. You have him come see me. We'll give him a try-out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the scout hands his card to Frank, we whip over to whe Teddy, his driver Jimmy Racine and their girlfriends, cok up, are laughing as a black cop, flashing his detective's shield, pretends to frisk Jimmy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's this? (taking a .45 from Jimmy's pocket) Oh, that's it, I'm taking you in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (joking) You can't take me in for that, I got       a license for that, motherfucker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gives the gun back) This then - (the pile of coke on the coffee table) But first -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cop sucks up a line before pretending to cuff Jimmy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, now I'm arresting you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody laughs.    Teddy peels $100's from a money clip

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let him go.   This is for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is that, a bribe?     Oh, now you're all under arrest.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The cop pretends to arrest them all, but what he doesn't pretend is the hand he puts on Jimmy's girlfriend's breas as he frisks her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was quick but Jimmy saw it, even though his girlfriend didn't react. The cop, oblivious, is cuffing Teddy now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm taking you all in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said, what the fuck was that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room explodes with a boom and the detective crumples the floor, clutching at his leg, blood running through hi fingers onto the carpet. Frank stares.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, he's all right. I just shot him in the leg. You got a health plan, what are you complaining about. He's fine. Here - (peels off some money) Five hundred all right? Six? Look, he's feeling better all the time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly, Frank grabs Jimmy and throws him against the wa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Ana tries to clean the blood stain on the rug with sal and soda water, Frank sits with his five brothers in the debris-strewn aftermath of the party. Silence before:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't have this kind of stupidity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was an accident.   He feels terrible about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He doesn't feel shit, coked up all the time. Get rid of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank. He's your cousin. What's he gonna do? Go back home? I'll talk to him. I'll straighten him out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank looks at Teddy in his tinted Jackie Fox-like goggle glasses - like he's going to straighten anybody out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gimme those glasses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?   Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank pulls them from Teddy's face and crushes them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richie sifts through the morning mail at his desk. Stops on an envelope from the New Jersey Bar Association. As he works up the nerve to open it, Spearman, Jones and Abruzz organize the Italian wise guys' photos on the T.O.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ice Pick Paul goes here -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, he's under Benny Two-Socks -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you're thinking of Benny the Bishop. Benny Two-Socks is Tosca's deadbeat son- in-law.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jonesy's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richie comes over, studies the Table of Organization a moment, then begins untacking the photos from the top dow

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What're you doing?     We just -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For a cop the uppermost thing is the arrest. For a prosecutor, the arrest is nothing without the evidence to convict. We don't have any real evidence on anyone on this board, so they're coming down. We're starting over from the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you, a prosecutor all of a sudden?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richie tacks his exam results onto the T.O.       He pass

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richie and the Amigos observe a buy from a parked car, th blue cellophane changing hands. Ignoring the buyer as he walks away, they keep watching the seller.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The seller is observed coming out of a mechanics garage. Richie ignores him as he walks away, watching instead the garage. Eventually, a mechanic wiping his hands on a rag steps out, and Richie raises a camera. The image of the mechanic - a supplier - freezes -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A slightly-blurred photo of the mechanic goes up on a new almost bare Table of Organization.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Atop of a telephone pole, Abruzzo, dripping with lineman equipment, works to attach a `slave' to the lines -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bare room. Richie, Jones and Spearman eating take-out foo as tape recorder reels turn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those snow tires you give me last time come in yet? I'm going to want some more of them, gimme one and a half more of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The detectives laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toback has Richie sign a voucher for $20,000 cash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is more than a year's salary, Richie. If it disappears, I won't be able to get it for you again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It'll never be out of my sight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jones tapes a tape recorder the size of a pack of cigaret to Richie's bare chest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Undercover in a wise guy's cashmere sweater and slacks, Richie watches the mechanic count the $10,000 he's given him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's got to be `Blue Magic.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, yeah, it's `Blue.' You can pick it up here tomorrow. Where's the rest of the money?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's half. I'll give you the other half tomorrow when you give -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, no, I don't do that.    Go fuck yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richie rather reluctantly hands over the rest of the 20K.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. SPEARMAN'S CAR
dialogues.text: Spearman watches the pickup truck driven by the mechanic change lanes up ahead - heading for the George Washington Bridge - and glances over concerned to Richie, who is changing the cashmere sweater for an old t-shirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's going into New York.   Are we?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are they going to do, arrest us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They could. New York cops.     They can do worse than that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not losing that money.    Go.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: As Spearman follows the truck, the George Washington Brid linking Jersey to Manhattan, looms in the windshield ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The pickup pulls to the curb outside a Pleasant Avenue grocery store. As the guy enters the place, Spearman's ca stops long enough for Richie to climb out, and continues Richie crosses the street, tries to see who the guy is talking to inside, but he's just buying a cup of coffee t go. Spearman's car turns the corner to circle around the block. As soon as it's gone, the man emerges from the restaurant with the coffee and walks straight at Richie w has to double back quickly not to be seen Richie sees a delivery truck double-parked, guys unloadin crates. Hears a horn and knows it's must be Spearman stuc on the side street. The mechanic starts his truck. Desperate not to lose him (and his money), Richie hurries over to a taxi stopped at a light, flashes his badge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get the fuck out of the car!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The driver realizes the man outside his taxi is crazy and tries to get his window rolled up. Reaching in, Richie ge his arm stuck, pulls at the lock, yanks the door open, dr the driver out, breaking the cabbie's arm, and jumps in. He swings the cab into opposing lanes to get around traff screeches around the corner, glimpses the truck far up ah - guns the engine, flies through a red light, glances at mirror at the cars that just missed him almost colliding The truck turns up ahead, and Richie barrels through anot red light, turns the corner and keeps the truck, a couple car-lengths ahead - in sight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richie curbs the cab as the guy goes into a dingy pizza parlor. Richie climbs out, crosses the street. Coming pas the place, he tries to look inside without breaking strid

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: From around a corner, striding toward him, come four men looking like Gestapo thugs in leather coats, manicured ha the Princes of the City. Richie detours into an alley as they enter the restaurant. Richie peers in at the restaurant kitchen through a grimy basement window. Watches Trupo and his SIU detectives bur in, guns drawn. They rough everybody up, get some down on the floor. One detective gathers the money and stuffs it a bag. Another gathers the dope. The mechanic tries to protest and Trupo slaps him down with his pistol. Richie keeps watching as the NY cops arrest no one - but take the dope and the money (Richie's money) - and stride out as abruptly as they appeared, like bandits. As they come past Richie -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's my money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The fuck are you. What money?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richie shows them his Bureau of Narcotics ID.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bills are sequenced and registered with the Essex County Prosecutors Office. All begin with CF3500. Take a look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of them checks some of the bills and sees he's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goddamn it, I thought we had a score. I thought I had a fucking Chris-Craft sitting in my driveway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honest mistake. Just give it back to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three of the four cops laugh. It's an affable gang of thieves. The one who doesn't laugh hangs back as the othe start off. He examines Richie's New Jersey ID.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When's the last time I was in Jersey? Let me think. Never. What're you doing coming over here without letting anybody know? You don't know you can get hurt doing that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Trupo smiles; Richie smiles) You got your money. Now, never, ever, come into the city again unannounced. You come in to see a fuckin Broadway show you call ahead first to see if it's okay with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trupo pats him on the back and leaves with the others.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do we hate most? Isn't it the transgressions of others we fear we're capable of ourselves?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's very late.    Richie and Toback are alone.      Even

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richie - cops are like -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I know, like everyone else. Some of them will steal no matter what. There can be a camera on them they'll do it. Some'll never do it. The rest are capable of either, depending how their department leans ... Only theirs isn't leaning, it's fallen over. The patrol cars don't even stop in Harlem, just roll down the window so the dealers can throw the money in. I saw drops made on precinct steps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What were you doing there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's where this dope is coming from. Blue Magic. Out of New York. What am I supposed to do, ignore it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cab driver's filed aggravated assault and grand theft charges -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wouldn't stop. Motherfucker almost ran me over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - which he may reconsider depending on the amount the State of New Jersey offers to settle -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told him I was a cop.      I showed him my identification.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You stole his cab and broke his arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was chasing your 20 thousand dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to hear about you going into New York anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then my investigation's over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not listening to me. I said: I don't want to hear about it ... You do whatever you have to do, go wherever you have to go to find out who's bringing this shit into the country ... Just don't tell me. (turns to leave) Get some sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richie - in robe and underwear - opens the door to find a woman in the hall holding a briefcase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Roberts?    I'm here for our appointment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has no idea who the black woman is. An old girlfriend he's forgotten maybe. Behind him, Vida can see a stewarde buttoning up her uniform by a little travel case on wheel The apartment itself, she can also see, is a mess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From Child Social Services?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 156   EXT/INT. TONY ZACA'S BACKYARD & POOL HOUSE - DA Barbecue after their Sunday softball game. Richie and his O.C. friends - wise guys - still in their brown and orang Weequahie jerseys, drinking beer, cooking hamburgers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you asked me to be your son's godfather, I took it very seriously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. Richie and Tony Zaca relax in the den-like pool house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said yes, I'd take on this responsibility, take care of your son, God forbid something happened to you -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tony, the things she's telling Child Social Services make me look very bad: Out all night. Lowlife informants hanging around.   Women -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Old friends like me. Richie feels horrible doing this.    Silence.   Then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all right. I understand. They ask me, I'll tell them what you want me to tell them. I'll lie for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. Tony nods, You're welcome.    Can tell there's something on Richie's mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't have to talk about it, you don't want. What do you hear about Blue Magic? Anything?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lot of sorrow and misery from guys being put out of business. That's all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing about who's bringing it in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guys down south is all I heard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Down south, Florida?   Cubans?   What.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. All I can tell you is whoever it is, they're upsetting the natural order of things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Among the framed family photos around them, is a picture of Tony's uncle, Albert Tosca.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Napoleonic statue of the same man on horseback in a fountain outside a castle-like mansion. Next to it "ride" three others on marble horses - a woman and two children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pull -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A clay pigeon sails out across the manicured garden. A shotgun blast shatters it. The man with the gun - Albert Tosca - hands another to Frank. As Frank sets to shoot, A can seen behind them, with Tosca's wife in the opulent house, looking uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The whole place was imported brick by brick from Gloucestershire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's very nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Tosca nods. Ana nods. A strained silence thicker tha the tapestries settles over them until -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pull -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The shotgun booms -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As servants stand by, Tosca and his wife and their only guests - Frank and Ana - finished with lunch, get up from the table in the formal Formal dining room.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: As Mrs. Tosca leads Ana off to give her a tour of the hou the men head off the other way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's a lovely girl.    You should marry her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too many things to look after right now to think about that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank. That's a mistake. If I may say. Don't take her for granted, girl like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They enter a rich, wood-paneled study lined with books.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You interested in history, Frank? The events that have brought us to where we are today? You know who was? Bumpy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bumpy was interested in a lot of things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I always wonder if people know when history's being made. And what they're doing at the time. This, for instance, could be a historic moment, and you're sipping a glass of ice water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Droplets snake down Frank's glass. He senses Tosca has finally gotten around to why he was invited here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bumpy and I did a lot of business together, as you know. Whatever he needed, he'd come to me and I'd do my best to provide it. He came to me, I didn't go to him, is the point I'm trying to make. You know why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He didn't have what you needed. You had what he needed. We've always had to come to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.   Until now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tosca studies Frank, who is a study in inscrutability.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Monopolies are illegal in this country, Frank, because no one can compete with a monopoly. If they let the dairy farmers do that, half of them would go out of business tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just trying to make a living.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which is your right. Because this is America. But not at the unreasonable expense of others. That's un-American. (he studies Frank) You know the price you pay for a gallon of milk doesn't represent its true cost of production. It's controlled. Set.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I set a price I think is fair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's very unfair, in fact. Your customers are happy, but what about your fellow dairy farmers? You're not thinking of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very calmly) I'm thinking of them as much as they ever thought of me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. I can see you're getting excited. Don't get excited. That's not why I invited you to my home. To get excited.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank doesn't look excited at all. He's the picture of calm. Tosca smiles benignly and gets up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here, I got something for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tosca opens a humidor, takes out a couple of Cuban cigars

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now what if - I'm just thinking out loud - you sold some of your inventory wholesale and I helped with the distribution.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't need it. I already got everything from 110th Street to Yankee Stadium, river to river.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which is a little mom and pop store compared to what I'm talking about. I could make you bigger than K-Mart. L.A., Chicago, Detroit, Vegas. I'm speaking nationwide. And I'd guarantee you peace of mind. You know what I mean by that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank does. It's a backhanded threat.        Tosca clips cigars with a gold guillotine

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank. You can see I'm a Renaissance man. Unfortunately not all my people are as enlightened. Ask them, What is civil rights, they don't know. They're not as open to change from the way things are done and who's doing it. But I can talk to them so there won't be any misunderstanding. That's what I mean by peace of mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank knows, in truth, he's not being given any choice in this matter. Still, maybe it's not so bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You pay what a kilo now, 75, 80? I'd consider 50. And I can get you as much as you want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tosca slips on his best poker face. Fifty thousand a kilo would be an extraordinary coup for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see, I was right. This is a historic moment. You're going to be bigger than Bumpy himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hands Frank one of the cigars, expertly prepared.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't smoke it here, unfortunately. Grace doesn't like it. Take it with you.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. TOSCA'S MANSION
dialogues.text: Doc waits by the car as Frank and Ana walk toward him. The Toscas wave goodbye from the front step of the mansio Frank slips the cigar into his top pocket as they climb i

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why would you trust these people, the way they look at you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They look at me like it's Christmas and I'm Santa Claus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They looked at us like we're the help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (kisses her cheek)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.   They're working for me now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A TV: Muhammad Ali, the black man's black man, and Joe Frazier, the white man's black man, at their 1971 Madison Square Garden press conference where Ali says as much. Most of the guys watching it. Richie isn't. He comes over to Table of Organization. Tacks his Bar Association notice to it. Regards the photographs, like tentacles of octopus yet to have a head. Only the lowest section is made up of blacks (including Charlie Williams and Jackie Fox, but not Frank Lucas). Th rest of the faces are white and stop about midway up. They've hit a wall they can't get past.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another TV here: Howard Cosell, ringside at the Garden as the first early fans arrive, pointing out that the fight, because of the political stand Ali's taken, is less about boxers than war versus anti-war. Frank chooses a linen jacket from his extensive color- coordinated racks of Phil Cromfeld suits as Ana, in her lingerie, puts on make-up at a vanity. He comes up behind her and sets down a small jewelry box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The TV in the background as Richie puts a camera with a l lens in a sports bag and reaches for his coat -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ana's reflection in the vanity mirror as Frank slips the engagement ring on her finger. She wipes at a tear, then gets up and hugs him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She kisses him.     Admires the ring.     And -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I bought you something, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She crosses past the TV, takes a garment bag down from he side of the closet, lays it on the bed next to Frank's su jacket. She takes hold of the zipper but doesn't immediately pull it, hoping perhaps to create some dramat tension.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She unzips the bag like she's unveiling great art. But instead of seeing what's inside, we're allowed only Frank reaction: his smile of anticipation slowly changing to chagrin.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. MADISON SQUARE GARDEN
dialogues.text: Richie observes celebrities and gangsters arriving in limousines - Sammy Davis Jr. and his wife, Joe Louis and his, Tosca and some of his guys - then enters the arena a another limo pulls up. Ana climbs out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on. You look great. (no one else emerges) You want to miss the fight? Come on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finally, a patent leather shoe pokes out, sets down on th curb. Then its mate beside it. The shoes step away from the limo and -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pre-fight. Richie, blended in with the a group of press photographers, regards the organized crime figures ringsi He takes a few pictures with the long lens camera as -

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The owner of the gleaming patent leather shoes is shown t his second row ringside seat just behind the sports write and we move up the full-length chinchilla coat to Frank's uneasy expression - Richie's camera roams the faces of the prime ticket holde ringside: organized crime figures, celebrities, politicia women with plunging necklines and platinum hair -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richie can't believe it's Joe Louis brushing past him -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Louis -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe looks back as Richie approaches him -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, but I just have to tell you, sir, you were a hero to me growing up. I still push elevator buttons eight times for the rounds you beat Billy Conn in. For luck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Louis acknowledges Richie only slightly more than not at all. Turns away to join his friends. Richie watches after him, stung by Louis's disregard. He snaps a picture of an Italian wise guy he doesn't recognize ... sifts the camera's view past Frank in the chinchilla coat ... then returns to him, watches as Tosca and his guys sit down behind Frank. Richie can't hear - but can see - their good-natured exchange -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Frank, you keep that hat on, I'm gonna miss the fight -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The odd thing to Richie is, Chinchilla's seat is better than all the Italians'. Detective Trupo notices this, too Richie focuses on the Chincilla's date, a stunning girl, beauty queen, then shifts back to her boyfriend who's now shaking the proffered hands of other Italians, then Don King. Joe Louis himself - who barely acknowledged Richie' existence - comes over and playfully exchanges "punches" with the man in the chinchilla coat. A sudden roar from the crowd as the lights go out except for the spot on the ring. Ali and Frazier are coming down the steps through the crush of fans and reporters, preced by soldiers carrying flags -

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Richie tries to find the guy in the chinchilla coat, but he's hidden by a flag. Then he glimpses him again just as Ali shakes his hand before climbing into the ring - Flashbulbs pop throughout the arena as Robert Goulet begins the National Anthem. Ali pointedly doesn't sing along. Richie frames the shadowy figure in the chinchilla coat, focuses as sharp as he can in the bad light, and snaps the shutter -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richie tacks the photograph of the man in the chinchilla coat to his Table of Organization - low and off to the si by other pieces of the puzzle that don't fit, other new faces with no names. Spearman holds a scrap of paper -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's is the plate number on the limo. Check with the company, who rented it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a supplier at most. Or just a pimp. We'd've heard of him otherwise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, he's bigger than that. His seats were phenomenal; better than Al Tosca's. Joe Louis and Ali shook his fuckin hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They look from Tosca's high position on the board to Fran low one, and a wedding march played in traditional fashio on organ begins and carries over:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From above, a sea of ladies' hats, all coral and pink. Below, Frank stands at the altar, waiting for his bride.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His name is Frank Lucas ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toback sifts through documents Richie has gathered: limousine company records, Frank's thin arrest record, mu shots of him years younger, the photograph from the fight and some more from subsequent surveillances.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Originally from Greensboro, North Carolina. Couple of arrests years ago. Gambling, robbery, unlicensed firearm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For fifteen years he was Bumpy Johnson's collector, bodyguard and driver. He was with him when he died.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ana's family and friends on one side of the aisle, the extended Lucas family - on the other. Frank's mother look at her eldest son at the altar with pride.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five brothers, he's the oldest, lots of cousins, all living here now, spread out around the boroughs and Jersey. The brothers are -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Lucas brother hands some dry cleaning to Spearman -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eugene Lucas in Brooklyn -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another Lucas brother examines a lamp with a frayed cord brought in by Jones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Earl Lucas in Newark -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another brother at the register, hands Abruzzo a receipt

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lester Lucas in Queens -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another brother is photographed by Spearman from a parked car as he changes tires on a car up on a hoist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Turner Lucas, the Bronx -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richie kicks a dent into the fender of his old car.

dialogues.speaker: EXT/INT. BODY SHOP
dialogues.text: As an appraiser writes up an estimate, Richie observes Teddy, attending to paperwork inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Teddy Lucas, in Bergen County.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A photograph of Teddy goes up on the T.O. next to Frank a the other brothers and some cousins -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Except for the chinchilla coat, which no one can explain, Frank's life seems orderly and legitimate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Best Man Teddy standing next to Frank at the altar as the bride is escorted down the aisle by her father. Tight on Frank in a beautiful tuxedo -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A light goes on in a penthouse window. Down below, by his parked car, Richie shivers in the early morning cold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gets up early. Five a.m.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Has breakfast at a Midtown place, usually alone.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. DINER
dialogues.text: Richie tosses a glance inside a restaurant as he passes t window to where Frank sits eating at a table, Doc nearby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then goes to work. Meeting with his accountant, or lawyer, dropping in on one of the several office buildings he owns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nights, he usually stays home. When he does go out, it's to a club or dinner - with his new wife - friends, celebrities, sports figures - never O.C. guys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richie sits in his car across from Small's where bouncers keep out people like him. Frank, Ana, Wilt Chamberlain an his wife emerge from the restaurant together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sundays he takes his mother to church. Then drives out to change the flowers on Bumpy's grave. Every Sunday, no matter what.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank's mother tearfully watches her son slip a ring onto Ana's finger next to the fat engagement diamond - before Ana, in turn, puts a gold band on Frank's. The minister pronounces them husband and wife, the veil is lifted, and they kiss to great applause -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As a photographer takes the official photograph of the wedding party on the steps of the church -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lou Toback looks from a surveillance photo of the wedding party in his hands, to Richie's Table of Organization: Th Lucas brothers and cousins - in the streets of New York a New Jersey, arranged in some imagined hierarchy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not your typical day in the life of a dope man, Richie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neither was Bumpy Johnson's and he owned Harlem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think Frank Lucas took over for Bumpy Johnson? His driver? That's a little far-fetched.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it?   Everything he does, he does like Bumpy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bumpy never wore a chinchilla coat in his life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We haven't seen that again. That apparently has been retired to the closet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank and Charlie look on as Ana throws the bouquet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's the most beautiful bride I ever saw, Frank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish Bumpy could've met her.     I wish she could've met him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looking at the Lucas Table of Organization -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you got on him you can use in court? Because this isn't it. You try this without informants and powder, no one's going to jail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Won't get any informants. Not inside. It's like a Sicilian family. Like he's structured his own family the same way to protect himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly like one, like a scene from The Godfather as Fran dances with Ana before the reception guests.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Being with Bumpy long as he was, he would have been around Italians a lot. Enough to learn that much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rice rains down on the bride and groom as they climb into the back of the Towncar. Doc comes around to the driver's side, gets in and slowly pushes through the crush of gues waving and throwing kisses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it's not even Frank Lucas I want. I want to know who he's working for: Which Italians are bringing the heroin in.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. TOWNCAR / NEW YORK
dialogues.text: Flanked front and rear by Frank's security, the marriage car moves along a rain-slick street. The newlyweds cuddle in back. Another car pulls up alongside - Trupo's Shelby and Doc's right hand instinctively comes off the steering wheel to settle on his holstered gun. Trupo smiles and shakes his head, no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Lincoln and security cars and Trupo's Shelby parked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Ana)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stay in the car As Frank and Doc climb out, Frank motions to his other security men to remain calm, he'll handle this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Frank. If Frank is surprised Trupo knows his name, he doesn't sh it, or anything else except an air of professional courte

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Detective. Trupo looks in at Ana in the back seat, smiles at her. Sh turns her head away and closes the door. Trupo leads Fran away for a private conversation -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sure you done the right thing? She's a beautiful girl - there's no question - but she's got an attitude on (her) -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen   to me. Before you say another word -   about her - or me - remember that you're   saying it on the most important fuckin   day of my life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man walks around in a fifty thousand dollar chinchilla coat and he never even bought me a cup of coffee? Something wrong there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what you're talking about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You pay your bills, Frank?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to keep talking, talk to my lawyer, here's his card. You call him, because we're done here -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you pay your bills, I asked you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you're not getting your share, it's not my fault, go ask the chief of police.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's my share? You don't even know me. Maybe I'm special.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you're all the fuckin same.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shows his shield) What does that say? (Frank ignores him) Special - Investigations - Unit. See that word there? "Special." (he takes out a restaurant business card) Ten grand, first of each month, delivered here.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Frank ignores the card, stares at Trupo like he's a fool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Detective ... There are some things you don't do. This is one of them. Not on a man's wedding day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank's resolve throws Trupo off his rhythm.           He

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have a nice honeymoon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank doesn't carry Ana across the threshold. He strides leaving her at the front door, throws a match in the gas fireplace, comes back from the bedroom a moment later wit the $50,000 chinchilla coat and throws it on the flames.

dialogues.speaker: TELEVISION IMAGE
dialogues.text: A march on Washington, protesting the war (archive).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The report continues on a TV here as Teddy's driver, Jimm Racine, yells at his girlfriend -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck you, I'm not telling you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She comes past the TV and into the kitchen past a table covered with dope paraphernalia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is my fuckin dope? You and your girlfriends take it again? I'll fuckin kill you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She yanks open a drawer, grabs a knife and slashes it at him. He grabs a gun and she runs for the stairs -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He chases her into the street, yelling, raises the gun an fires, and she goes down, clutching at her butt, moaning

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moaning here, too.   Richie's lawyer-ex-girlfriend, in be with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richie, yes, fuck me like a cop, not a lawyer - (the phone rings)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, God, Richie, no - don't answer it - (he reaches to pick it up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, no -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richie. Newark just picked up one of the celebrities on our Wall of Fame: Teddy's driver. For attempted murder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richie's had Jimmy Racine brought over. Sits with him as the Three Amigos watch from the shadows. Just coming off his high, and the attempted murder, Jimmy looks disorient as he sits in cuffs in the dungeon-like basement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because it's an attempted homicide, that's Grand Jury. Now, that Grand Jury could come in very favorably. Might turn out to be Attempted Manslaughter. Self Defense even. She had a knife. Depends on how I want to deal with you. You see where this is going. Jimmy looks around at the basement dungeon with concern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The fuck is this place?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's say you beat it somehow. What do you think Cousin Frank'll think of that? He knows you had to sit here listening to something like this. And then you beat an attempted murder? Is he stupid? He'll assume you talked. Jimmy can easily imagine that scenario and it frightens h

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You fucked up, Jimmy. But nobody knows. Frank doesn't know. Yet. Do you want him to read about it in the paper? Or do you want to walk out of here - no bail, no trial - just walk out, now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmy has thought about it all night and walks out of the building into the chilly morning air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmy?   Look at me -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmy looks over his shoulder as if Richie just called to him from it, which he didn't. There's no one in sight -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any time I want to change my mind? I don't like the quality of your work? I can find a witness saw you shoot your girlfriend. It just took me a while. I even know what he'll look like. He'll look just like you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Teddy's car comes around a corner and down the street.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: Jimmy Racine, wired, looks in the rear view mirror at Ted in the back seat, and, behind him, Richie's car following

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richie keeps Teddy's car in view ahead. Glances in his mirror at the cars following him. His detectives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The detectives' cars parked behind a warehouse. Richie peers into binoculars at: Teddy's car parked by Frank's outside another warehouse loading dock. Frank gets out, discusses something with his brother, comes past Jimmy to some men in bloody white coats. He talks to them, returns to his car, takes a valise from the trunk. He snaps it open revealing stacks of cash, han it over and walks to a semi-truck, glancing once in Richi direction. Though he can't see anyone there he gives a wa to them - or is it to the truck driver to pull out -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like Bumpy used to do every Thanksgiving, Frank and his brothers, from the back of the truck, hand out hundreds o freshly-butchered turkeys to the poor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank, in an apron, carries in a huge cooked turkey as th extended Lucas family gathers around the table. It's like Norman Rockwell painting -

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. ALLEY / ROOMS HARLEM
dialogues.text: Another Thanksgiving picture: addicts shooting up and nodding out in alleys and dingy rooms. Tight on needles, veins, spoons, filth -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richie alone at his kitchen table with a sandwich and a beer. The Macy's parade plays silently on his TV.

dialogues.speaker: A215 INT/EXT. TRUPO'S HOUSE
dialogues.text: A doorbell summons Trupo. He comes through his entry. Opens the front door. Finds no one there - except a large live turkey on the doorstep. He stares at it nonplussed, then looks up to a sound - a whoosh - as flames engulf th interior and spit out the windows of his Shelby Mustang .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The big knife in Frank's hand slices into the turkey and lifts meat onto a plate that's passed from hand to hand, family engaged in several conversations at once, laughing

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bathroom. Jimmy Racine, shirt off, wired, changes the batteries of the little tape recorder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmy comes out, tries to take a chair not too far from Frank who's watching his nephew toss pop-up flies for the younger kids to catch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stevie. Come over here. (the nephew comes over)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I heard you didn't show up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're     too busy to meet with Billy Martin?   After I set it up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stevie shifts around, not wanting to make Frank mad ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to play pro ball, I decided.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What're you   talking about? This is your dream since   you were their age - (the   younger kids) Maybe I can   set it up again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stevie just stands there, uncomfortable.         Finally

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not what I want. I want to do what you do, Uncle Frank. I want to be you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank stares at him unhappily.       Teddy comes over but barely notices.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got a problem.

dialogues.speaker: LATE AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: Jimmy Racine behind the wheel.       Frank and Teddy in b speaking quietly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's been cutting it so much it's down to two, three percent pure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You tested it. You're sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Teddy nods. Frank notices Jimmy looking at them in the re view mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The fuck you looking at?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car pulls up in front of a building in the clothing district. Jimmy stays while Teddy and Frank go inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie's club looks like a set from a blaxploitation film Frank and Teddy, led by a bodyguard, come past some turke carcasses and other remnants of Thanksgiving to where Jac and a couple friends cavort with some naked girls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank.   Welcome.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We need to talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great.   Girls, get out. The girls gather their things and leave. Frank wipes at a modern leather chair with his handkerchief, throws it awa sits. Jackie lays out a couple lines, offers Frank a roll up hundred dollar straw. Frank shakes his head, no thanks

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You talked to Charlie. You want to hear more about my Black Coalition. Let me explain it to you - But first, let me suck up a line of coke -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not why I'm here. (Jackie glances up from the powder. No?)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody's happy, Jackie. Charlie, Baz, the cops, the Italians, everybody. Everybody except you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then I don't understand. Why do you have to take something that's perfectly good the way it is, and wreck it? Jackie doesn't seem to understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brand names mean something, Jackie. Consumers rely on them to know what they're getting. They know the company isn't going to try to fool them with an inferior product. They buy a Ford, they know they're gonna get a Ford.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not a fuckin Datsun. (his look says, right?) Blue Magic is a brand name; as much a brand name as Pepsi. I own it. I stand behind it. I guarantee it and people know that even if they don't know me any more than they know the chairman of General Foods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the fuck are you talking about, Frank?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What you're doing, as far as I'm concerned, when you chop my dope down to five percent, is trademark infringement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That.   That's what this is about.      Jackie nods, but

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With all due respect, Frank, if I buy something, I can do whatever I want with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not true. That's where you're wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I buy a car, I can paint it, God damn it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie, you don't need to. You don't need to make more money than you can with Blue the way it is. No one does. At a certain point it's just greed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want, Frank?    You want me to call it something else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to insist. You call it Blue Magic, that's misrepresentation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine. I'll call it Red Magic, even though it doesn't sound as good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all I'm saying.   Wrap it in red cellophane and -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pink Magic.   Black Magic -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whack it down to nothing, tie a bow around it and call it Blue Dogshit if you want, just don't let me catch you doing this again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie regards Frank for a long moment ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Catch me? Insist? Infringement? I don't like these words as much as please - thank you - sorry to bother you, Jackie. These are better words to use you come into my place without an invitation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie waits to hear a kinder word but Frank doesn't offe one. Jackie nods, Fine, okay, but it's more like a warnin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank pulls a girl off Teddy's lap and points him toward the door. Jackie watches them leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They emerge from the building to where Jimmy waits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give me the keys; take a cab home.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: Frank and Teddy driving in silence.        Eventually -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't go over there any more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Teddy doesn't like it, but nods. Suddenly his face is illuminated by light reflecting in the rear view mirror, unmarked police car behind them, flashing its brights.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all right, pull over, what are they going to do? Give us a ticket?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Teddy isn't as calm as he begins to pull over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Trupo and his partner climb out of their car and appro Teddy's -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank?   Some of it's in the trunk. Frank regards him with utter disbelief. Teddy shies as if he expects to get hit. The SIU detectives arrive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Frank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Detective. How's it going?        You have a nice Thanksgiving?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did not, as a matter of fact.       Get out of the car. The Lucases climb out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's the Shelby?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Shelby's gone, Frank. Trupo reaches in the driver's side window, takes the keys from the ignition and comes around to the trunk. Frank an Teddy exchange a glance as it opens. Silence. Then -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Want to come over here a minute, Frank? Six kilos of heroin are illuminated by the trunk light. Frank and Trupo regard it in silence. Then -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now what are we gonna do about this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're gonna shut the trunk and say good night, forget you pulled us over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got a better idea. Trupo reaches into the trunk, picks up two of the heroin bricks, tucks them under his arm and looks at Frank -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or would you rather I took it all and threw you and your brother in the fuckin river?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, would you rather it's your fuckin house blows up next time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They hold each others' stare for a long moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I loved that car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trupo closes the trunk and walks away with his cut of the heroin, calling to his partner -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the SIU cops walk to their car, the perspective shifts through binoculars: Richie watching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From outside the driver's side, Teddy's head, inside the car, suddenly smashes against the window, cracking it. Hi groan is interrupted by Frank's muffled voice -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you ever put me in a car with dope in it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richie comes in, opens the fridge and stares in, his mind elsewhere. A ringing phone pulls him out of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.   Tony.    How's it going?

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. TONY ZACA'S HOUSE
dialogues.text: Tony's wife and daughters can be seen in the suburban backyard. Here in the kitchen Tony and Richie watch kerne of popcorn bounce off the inside walls of the first Amana microwave oven. It's noisier than modern ones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The fuck is a `micro' wave?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a scientific force like atomic energy. It rearranges the molecules.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of what.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of anything. Of popcorn. You don't want to put your head in there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tony rakes out the plain, `pre-microwaveable' popcorn, using his hand. Gives some to Richie. Half of it's burnt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can get you one of these. Just like this, brand new. I'll have it delivered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, thanks.   I don't want one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tony hands Richie some snapshots: The Zaca family on the slopes of a resort, and in and outside a beautiful snow- dotted cabin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is nice, where's this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aspen.   Just got back.    Had a great time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like to ski Aspen some day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Know who we met? Burt Reynolds. I'm not kidding. Lot of people from Hollywood go up there now, buying up everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is your place?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you kidding? You know what it's worth? Ski-in-ski-out, five bedrooms, sauna, everything. We were guests. (pause) No ... No, that's your place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything seems to stop. Richie becomes aware of the sounds around them, the girls splashing around outside ..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't there something we can do - about leaving the big guy alone? You know who I mean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What Richie knows is that no matter what he does or says this point he's got a problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I don't report what you just said to me, you know I could be in a lot of trouble. If I do, then it's you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm hoping you won't do that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richie considers the room itself, measuring the odds of microphones and a recorder being in it somewhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not taping it. How do you know? Because we're friends and I'm telling you. This is a real offer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From who, your uncle? (Tony doesn't say)                                  Why would you do this? Why would you risk our friendship?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I care what happens to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You shouldn't have done it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had to. I had no choice. Neither do you. Leave Frank Lucas alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not important enough for you to do this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, he is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richie stares at Tony, then puts the pictures in his hand

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell Marie I'm sorry I had to leave. You can tell her why.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alone in the empty building, he stares at the T.O.: The higher echelon Italians like Tosca; lower echelon Harlem guys like Charlie Williams and Frank Lucas. He gets up then, untacks Frank's photograph from its lowl position and moves it to a place no black has ever occupi to the top of the pyramid - above the mafia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toback regards Frank's picture at top of the Lucas T.O.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INS, FBI, IRS - I can't get anything out of them. Nothing on his travel, his bank accounts, property holdings - nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's because they all think you're on the take and you think they are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They don't want this to stop. It employs too many people. Cops, lawyers, judges, probation officers, prison guards. The day dope stops coming into this country, a hundred thousand people lose their jobs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toback isn't as sure the corruption of the official world that complete.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richie.   Excuse me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spearman gestures to a couple of men in suits who want to talk to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richie and Tobacke regard the two stone-faced FBI agents

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who took it out? (nothing from the agents) If there's a contract on me, it would be nice to know who took it out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can't say without compromising our source. You understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.    I don't. Not when it's my life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you want, we can assign someone to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?    FBI?   You're going to protect me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richie almost laughs at the thought, looks to Toback. fact, none of this is funny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walking toward his apartment down its dark street, bag of groceries in arm, Richie becomes aware someone is followi him. He slows to let the figure get closer, closer, then turns fast, drops the guy and puts a gun to his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't shoot!    For God's sake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richie keeps the gun pressed against the guy's forehead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you Richard Roberts?      I got a subpoena.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richie and Laurie sit with their respective lawyers, wait for the judge to appear. He leans over -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laurie. I'm sorry I couldn't give you the kind of life you wanted. I'm sorry it was never enough. But don't punish me for being honest. Don't take my son away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stares at him in disbelief.        Then responds in a voice than his -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you saying? That because you were "honest" and didn't take money like every other cop, I left you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bailiff looks over, but she doesn't care.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't take money for one reason: to buy being dishonest about everything else. And that's worse than taking money nobody gives a shit about - drug money, gambling money nobody's gonna miss. (more people look over) I'd rather you took it and been honest with me. Or don't take it, I don't care. But don't then go cheat on me. Don't cheat on your kid by never being around. Don't go out and get laid by your snitches and secretaries and strippers. I can tell just by looking, she's one of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His lawyer.    Which is true.    Everyone's watching them

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think you're going to heaven because your "honest." You're not. You're going to the same hell as the crooked cops you can't stand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All rise -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The same judge who sends a collection plate around sits before Richie and Laurie and their attorneys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your honor, a lot has been said here today about how unsavory Mr. Roberts' environment is for a child. How dangerous it is. I'm sorry, but this is our world. This is where we live and we tell him, Protect us. We give him that responsibility, and then say, Oh, but we don't trust you to raise a child. We don't think you're fit for that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Silence. Sheila looks at him, but he's looking at Laurie, and speaks to her like they're alone in the room:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're right. This is no place for him. Around me. Take him. The further away the better. For him.

dialogues.speaker: TV IMAGE, (ARCHIVE)
dialogues.text: The lights on the Rockefeller Christmas tree blink on to applause. A carol begins and continues over:

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. FRANK'S CAR / FRANK'S PENTHOUSE
dialogues.text: Seats covered with Christmas presents. Doc, driving, sees Trupo's car parked out front Frank's penthouse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I see them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doc pulls to the curb outside Frank's building. As the doorman helps Doc with the big Christmas tree tied to the roof of the car, Frank crosses to Trupo's car with a coup of bottles of Crystal tied with holiday bows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here you go, boys.   Merry Christmas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie has come to visit. A Christmas carol plays as Fra strings the tree with some lights.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paying cops is one thing, I understand that. I been paying them since I was ten - put more of their kids through college than the National Merit Award. This is different, this Special Investigations Unit. They think they are special.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're fucking crooks.   No code of ethics.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank plugs the cord in and the tree lights up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone's been following me. Besides cops. I see cars where they shouldn't be. Guys I don't know -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They regard each other.    The carol continues over:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ana hangs tinsel on the tree as Frank gives the shepherd some dog toy presents he's bought. More to himself:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bumpy hardly ever went out at a certain point. He stayed in - read - watched TV - played chess. I thought he chose to lead a quiet life. He didn't. He couldn't go out without something happening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can still go out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where? With who? Everyone I know is under surveillance. I can't even be with my family at Christmas anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gets up, pets the dog, and looks out the window at Christmas angels stretched across the street, at people o the sidewalk, wondering perhaps which of them are underco cops, at Trupo's car, still parked outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you just pay who you have to pay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do pay them, I pay them all. Cops, accountants, lawyers, who don't I pay? Everybody. I pay them a fortune, it doesn't matter. It doesn't satisfy them. The more you pay, the more they expect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't start with them because they can't stop. It's like dope. They always want more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ana looks vulnerable. Frank almost feels bad that it's hi life and problems that have put them here. Eventually, to try to turn it around -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put on something nice, we're going out.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. FRANK'S PENTHOUSE BUILDING
dialogues.text: Frank and Ana emerge from a service elevator, come down dark hall and out the back door to an alley to where Doc waits with the car in the falling snow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank's car approaches Small's just as Jackie, with a Santa Claus hat on, climbs out of a sky blue Bentley with his entourage. Frank groans to Doc -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Around back?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck that. I'm not going to sneak into my own club. Just drive.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CHINESE TAKE-OUT PLACE
dialogues.text: Waiting for a take-out order under harsh fluorescent ligh

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to wait in the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go ahead, Frank.       I'll wait for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can carry it all?      We ordered a lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doc nods, go on, go with Ana. Frank hands him a couple twenties. Ana's already outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't forget the yellow sauce.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ana's half a block ahead, waiting outside the locked car the time Frank arrives and realizes -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doc's got the keys.   Let's go back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lights give me a headache, you go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not leaving you on the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get the keys, Frank, it's cold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts back through cascading snow.       Notices a ca slowly down the street -

dialogues.speaker: INT. CHINESE PLACE
dialogues.text: The cook dumps sizzling vegetables into a take-out contai and puts it in a bag -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car passes, continues to the end of the block, turns corner.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CHINESE PLACE
dialogues.text: Doc hands over money, waits for his change -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gimme some of that yellow sauce.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank sees the car again, coming around the corner, walks briskly back to where Ana waits. The car is almost upon them as he grabs her by the wrist and pulls her hard alon the sidewalk. The car guns its engine -

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. CHINESE PLACE
dialogues.text: As Frank pushes in past the doors with Ana, the windows explode. They dive to the floor, bullets ripping through the place. Doc draws his two guns and fires back at the car, hitting it a couple times as it screeches off. He gathers Ana and Frank off the floor like a presidential bodyguard, hustle them out to the car. Frank's shoulder is bleeding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You hit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the fuck was that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They pile in and Doc screeches away from the curb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heavy security in the hallways: Frank's own men and some cops he's got on the payroll. Ana steps from the elevator and hurries past, early edition New York paper in hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The brothers watch as a private doctor attends Frank's wounds. He seems all right fine except for the fact that someone had the fucking nerve to take a shot at him - and Charlie he sees in the newspaper - gunned down, dead, lur Weegee-like photo of him on the front page.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was it Jackie? (Frank doesn't say) I'll fuckin kill him whether it was or not, you tell me to. (nothing from Frank) What do you want us to do, Frank? We can't just sit here and -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who didn't like Charlie?   Everybody liked Charlie ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who shot at us? (Frank can't tell her) It doesn't matter. We're leaving.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She pulls a drawer open. Takes out their passports. Begins packing. The brothers watch, not sure what to do, or say. To them -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go home.   Go see your kids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He obviously wants to talk to Ana alone. Pulls away from the doctor. They all leave. Ana keeps packing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing?     Where've you been?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're leaving from here.      Money's in the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What money?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything from your mother's house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In your car?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's the car?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out front.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With ten million dollars in it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't count it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you crazy? Take it back to Teaneck. What are you doing driving around without security? Doc'll take you back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not going there, we're going to the airport. We're leaving the country.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To go where?    No, we're not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank, Charlie's dead. They tried to kill us. What else has to happen - ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He grabs her and holds her to calm her down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shhh.   Come on, now.   Shhh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He holds her close, waits for her breathing to slow befor

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are we going to go? Spain? China? Which fuckin place is it going to be?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can go anywhere we want.     We can live anywhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can run and hide is what you're saying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He slowly shakes his head: that's something he'll never d

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is where I'm from. This is where my family is. My business. My mother. This is my place. This is my country. This is America.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Statue of Liberty in morning light and mist rises fro the waters of the Hudson River.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richie, at his desk, looks up to see Trupo walking throug the squad room, followed by Spearman.
