dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Said he'll only talk to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trupo's attitude has completely changed from the first ti they met. He talks to Richie now like a fellow conspirato

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From what I hear, it was the Corsicans. The French Connection, Fernando Rey, the exporters Frank has put out of business. Now, I can take care of him in New York, but I don't want to have to worry every time he drives across the bridge to Jersey someone's gonna take another shot at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richie gives nothing away even as it stuns him that Trupo would speak to him this blatantly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We need to start working together. We need to step up our efforts. Next time their aim could be better. We need to keep this cash cow alive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmy Racine comes in - sees Trupo - and leaves - but not before Trupo has seen him. And now he sees the Lucas Tabl of Organization he didn't notice when he came in. Gets up and walks over to it now and takes a closer look. Sees Frank's picture at the top, like Enemy Number 1.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus. What the fuck you doing here? You actually going to arrest Frank Lucas? What's the matter with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm crazy. Can't you tell that? I'm crazy enough to shoot someone and make it look like an accident next time he comes over the bridge without my permission. Get the fuck out of New Jersey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They regard each other a moment before Trupo turns to lea

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A large TV shows chaotic scenes in Saigon. The US is pulling out of Vietnam. Tosca has come to see how Frank i recovering, and finds him, agitated, too long in bed even though it's only been a day, changing into a nice shirt, putting on his shoes -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "I can guarantee you peace of mind," you said. Do I look like a man with peace of mind to you? They shot at my wife. Who does that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who was it, which one of your people? I'll take that gun away and shove it up their ass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know that it was any of them, Frank. Neither do you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then maybe I'll kill them all just to make a fuckin point.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tosca seems more philosophical about it - like Bumpy migh have been - but it wasn't him who was shot at.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to know who it was? I can tell you. It was a junkie. Or a rival. Or some dumb ass kid trying to make a name for himself. Or someone you forgot to pay off. Or slighted without realizing it. Or someone you put out of business by being too successful. (pause) Success has a lot of enemies. Your success is who took a shot at you. How you gonna kill it? By being unsuccessful? You can be successful and have enemies, or unsuccessful and have friends. It's the choice we make.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A call has interrupted Nate's massage (and later activiti with a bevy of Thai girls. He wraps himself in a robe, takes the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank on a pay phone in a comfortable alcove with a stack of quarters. Other guests are gathered around a TV in the lounge that shows images of helicopters plucking diplomat off the roof of the American Embassy in Saigon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm watching the news.     Where the hell's everyone going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Home.    The war's over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just like that? We're going to leave the fuckin country to the communists?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We been here since 1961, Frank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank and Nate and their "army" of black servicemen and T thugs wind through the jungle with pack mules.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The same farm and hut as before. Frank and the Chinese General sip tea. The four million dollars in cash Frank brought sits on the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Opium plants are hearty enough to outlive any war. They'll still be here long after the troops are gone. But what are you going to do for transportation when the last US plane goes home?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll figure something out.      You'll see me again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The General seems fond of Frank, and not only because of the money on the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not in my best interest to say this, Frank ... but quitting while you're ahead is not the same as quitting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what my wife thinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you don't think she's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank doesn't say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mules are loaded up with burlap bags containing 3,000 kil of heroin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The mule train approaches the jungle that surrounds the opium farm. Nate's Thai thugs, left behind in sniper positions in the trees, stand ready to open fire if they have to as Frank, Nate, the soldiers and mules pass below

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They seem to have made it, winding back down through the jungle with the mules. Suddenly a barrage of gunfire erup from the trees - a couple of Nate's men are hit as the re dive for cover, shouting "Vietcong," and returning the fi Frank drops down from his mule, gets a pistol out and sho into the trees. Bullet-severed palm fronds rain down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give them half! Nate, pinned down by the mules, can't hear him over the noise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cut half of them loose!      The mules! Nate cuts the mule-train tether in the middle, slaps at t animals. As the freed mules disappear into a wall of tree the shooting subsides, then stops altogether. Smoke from all the gunfire rises like mist around the half dozen Tha and Americans lying dead on the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Teddy makes out with a girl in the back seat of his car. The pay phone just outside on the corner rings, and he ge out, steps past Jimmy, answers it -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Thai singer attempts Otis Redding on the little stage. Frank, at a table here, with a drink and a phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Newark.     Short Term Parking Lot 3.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you need it? Today?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tomorrow will be fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmy loiters close enough to the open pay phone, to hear Teddy's side of the conversation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Short Term Lot 3. This the Mustang were talking about ... Camero? ... What's the plate number? (writes on a napkin) Yeah, I got it ... I got it, Frank ... (sighs; reads from the napkin:) KA 760.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmy's come over to share his news with the detectives. But Richie isn't pleased with it - or with Jimmy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no Short Term Lot 3 at Newark. They're lettered, A, B, C, D -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just telling you what I heard -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you heard wrong!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmy shies back a step in case Abruzzo takes a swing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe he means the time?   3 o'clock?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And this isn't a Jersey plate. Or New York. Not with just two letters. It's three and three, not two and three -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's what he said -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then what the fuck is it -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The fuck should I know -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're fuckin lying -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's what he said.   I'm sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence.   They all look at each other.       After a mom

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: None of you ever been in the service? It's an Air Force tail number.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The plane, with that tail number, descends through clouds

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richie's entire staff of detectives, along with Toback, t DA and several customs agents, stand on the tarmac, watch the military plane taxiing toward them -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quiet sounds of suburban domesticity - chirping birds, a distant lawn mower -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cabin door slides up, the passengers begin emerging: Military officers, embassy personnel and families. Richie detectives and Toback watch him with concern as the offic passengers, met by a bevy of assistants, file past -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The kitchen. Frank's mother shows Ana some old photograph of Frank as a boy as they sip coffee. There's a tap on th glass French door. The women look up and see Trupo just outside it, and other police moving past. He waves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An Army captain approaches Richie's law enforcement group

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain, I'm Richard Roberts, Director of the Essex County Narcotics Bureau.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Front door. Trupo sort of waves a search warrant at Julie as invites himself in. The NY cops follow, fan out. Trupo and his detectives head upstairs -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The plane has been brought into a hangar where it's being taken apart like a car stripped by thieves. Inside the cabin, seats are removed and inspected, carpeting pulled panels unscrewed, lavatories dismantled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Downstairs - Ana and Frank's mother, guarded, can hear Trupo and his detectives, upstairs, ransacking a bedroom. Upstairs - the SIU detectives pull open drawers, throw clothes from the closets.   Trupo picks up an invitation a United Nations ball, tosses it down again. Finds a safe deposit box key in a sock drawer, puts it in his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The engines and landing gear are disassembled, the tires opened up and searched. A nozzle plunges into a toilet an pumps out the contents into barrels detectives fish throu with gloved hands -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ana is taken upstairs, brought before the SIU detectives who wait for the NYPD cops to leave the room. The place has been torn apart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your husband's illustrious career is over. The Feds are going to come in and take it all. Everything. But not before I get my gratuity. Where's the money?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There was some on that dresser, but it's gone now so I guess you (took it) -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The money! The getaway money Frank and every other gangster keeps in his house!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you leave now, there's a chance Frank might not kill you -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trupo slaps her hard across the face -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richie, off by himself, watches with a growing sense of panic as the mechanics, detectives and customs agents beg removing the metal skin from the plane. Coffins are being off-loaded.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Downstairs, Mama Lucas puts washcloth on Ana's swollen cheek. They can hear the search continuing upstairs: thin being ripped from the walls, the walls themselves splinte apart with sledgehammers, glass breaking. To Mama Lucas -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They've looked everywhere and found nothing. The plane, in fact, hardly resembles a plane anymore - no panel left that hasn't been removed, no cavity not probed - except - Richie's glance settles on the military caskets as they'r loaded onto a truck, armed soldiers standing guard -

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. MAMA LUCAS'S TEANECK, N.J. HOUSE
dialogues.text: Frank's bedroom has been destroyed. Trupo, standing at a window glances out at the sound of a barking of a dog to Frank's German shepherd down in its kennel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richie gets up slowly and approaches the coffins as -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trupo crosses the lawn toward the kennel and barking dog

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richie stands over the nearest coffin -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Open it.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The army captain regards the detective for a long moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The warrant permits me to search the plane and its cargo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The captain doesn't comply. Richie moves to open the coff himself and every soldier's shouldered rifle immediately comes into firing position, aimed at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you don't have my permission.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richie stares at the weapons and the uniformed men holdin them, safeties off, fingers on the triggers; all they're waiting for is their commander's order to fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't need it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trupo regards the shepherd snarling at him from behind th kennel fence. Comes around back. Pushes at the frame. It moves a little, like it's levered -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With the rifles still pointed at him, Richie kneels down, pulls the latches of the coffins, half expecting to hear accompanying barrage of gunfire. He lifts the lid. Sees a long black body bag inside -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trupo comes around to the front of the kennel again with gun out and aims it at the dog. As he fires -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richie pulls at the zipper, parting the plastic body bag, revealing the remains of a young soldier -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dead dog slides against the fencing as Trupo overturn the kennel to reveal Frank's stash of cash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richie and Toback sit before the Federal Attorneys and customs agents. The US Attorney hangs up a phone ... then

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was a military transport plane. If there was heroin on board then someone in the military would have to be involved. Which means that even as it fights a war that's claimed 50,000 Americans lives, the military is smuggling narcotics. Richie's in serious trouble and knows it.    As does Toba

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's how these events are being interpreted by General Easton in that call to me. That someone employed by the this office believes the United States Army is in the drug trafficking business - and is trying to prove it by desecrating the remains of young men who've given their lives in the defence of democracy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are drugs on that plane -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut the fuck up. Richie does, but can't conceal the contempt he feels for these men who've never spent a minute on the street but a as if know more than him, and who are, in the unfortunate organization of his world, his superiors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it any wonder then, because of your actions, the entire federal narcotics program is now in jeopardy of being dismantled as completely and enthusiastic- ally as that fucking transport plane? That's what you've accomplished Mr. Roberts. Single-handedly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had good information the target of my investigation was bringing dope in on that plane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that target is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank Lucas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one in the room, except Richie and Toback, has ever heard the name. The federal men regard one another blankl

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?  Who's Frank Lucas? (no one seems to know) Who's he work for? Which family?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not Italian. He's black.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now there's a longer, even deeper silence, before -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that supposed to be some kind of joke? You're this close to the end of your career in law enforcement, you're making jokes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I believe Frank Lucas is above the mafia in the dope business. I believe he buys direct from the source in Southeast Asia, cuts out all the middlemen, and uses US military planes and personnel to bring pure No. 4 heroin into United States.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richie is looking at faces that are still trying to make sense out of his ridiculous theory. Toback tries to come his defense -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richie has a lot of experience -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does he. And how many arrests has he made in his so-called investigation?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was promised when I took this job, it was about real arrests.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does that mean `none?'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have cases against most of Frank's organization. Not him -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (more to the others) Frank's organization -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No fucking nigger has accomplished what the American Mafia hasn't in a hundred years!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, you'd know, sitting here, having never been on the (street) -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lou, get this fucking kike out of here -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richie goes for him and lands several punches before Toba and the others can pull him off.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. AIRPORT HANGAR OFFICE
dialogues.text: Richie and Toback walk briskly across the lobby -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was out of line, Richie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richie isn't really listening. Strides past his detective on his way out of the building. To Spearman -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's over.   You're shut down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toback watches as the detectives follow after Richie striding toward his car.

dialogues.speaker: A303 INT/EXT. AIRPORT TERMINAL
dialogues.text: Frank comes out with an airline representative to find Do waiting for him. He can tell immediately something's wron

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank slaps a cartridge into the butt of a pistol.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ten million dollars means nothing to me.

dialogues.speaker: B303 CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Ana stares at the floor. It all just seems to get worse a worse. They had their chance to get out and missed it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This - is his death warrant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He lightly touches his wife's bruised face and walks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He comes down the stairs to where Doc waits.         As t for the door -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frankie -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank glances to where his mother sits in the living room Nods to Doc to say, Get the car, I'll be out in a minute. Goes over to his mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sit down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sits. She studies him in a way she hasn't since he was little. Eventually -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you'd have been a preacher, your brothers would be preachers. If you'd been a soldier, they'd be soldiers. Do you know that? (he doesn't say) They all came here because of you. You called and they came running. They look up to you. They expect you to always know what's best. (pause) But even they know you don't shoot cops. Even I know that. Ana knows it. You seem to be the only one who doesn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that where I'm going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never asked you where all this came from because I didn't want to hear you lie to me. Don't lie to me. Don't do that, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's not pleading, she's telling.       Silence.    Then

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you really want to make things so bad for your family they'll leave you? Because they will. She will - (points upstairs) I know I will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank has some trouble looking at her. But then gets up. Walks toward the front door to leave. Hesitates near it a long moment. Then turns and walks upstairs. Trupo will live, at least for now, because of her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Down in the basement, the body bags are lifted from the wooden coffins. Set down on tables. The bags unzipped and the bodies removed. A rack of clean uniforms is brought in. The morticians begin dressing the corpses and applying make-up on the dr gray skin. New white military caskets are trundled in. Gold handles lifted. The bodies, clothed and painted now, are deposite on the silk linings. The lids of the coffins come down an cellophane bags containing folded flags are taped on top.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The white caskets are taken to a loading dock, put in a military truck. Papers are signed, copies exchanged. As the truck drives off -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two black privates on janitorial duty come into the room where the original plain wooden coffins have been discard They remove the lids, then the finely-crafted false botto revealing in 4-inch cavities of each, tightly-packed bric of Double UO Globe heroin. As they take them out, a gospe choir begins and continues over:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A laundry truck idles. Stevie, the Lucas nephew who could have played for Yankees, jumps down, helps the two privat toss several laundry bags into the back of the truck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A minister on the steps welcomes the congregation which includes Frank, his mother, and Ana -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The laundry truck comes past a guard gate, leaves the bas drives past a stand of trees. As it passes, Richie, parke by his detectives' cars, recognizes the young driver - wh wearing the same Yankee baseball cap in his T.O. photo. As Richie and his detectives climb into their cars, two Lucas cars fold in behind the laundry truck. The detectiv follow at a distance -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sea of ladies' hats from above move in time with the gospel choir. As always, no matter what else is going on his complicated life, Frank sits with his mother and Ana their usual pew. The gospel music continues over:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank emerges from the church, kisses his mother and Ana put them in a car with a driver. He climbs into Doc's alone. His mother watches, wondering perhaps if he intend to go kill Trupo after all. As Doc's car leaves, so does another.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. RICHIE'S CAR
dialogues.text: The laundry truck approaches a ramp leading to the George Washington Bridge. Richie, a couple of car lengths behind follows. The truck continues straight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From overhead, the laundry truck, the gun car and the van and the detectives' cars following them all - converge fr different directions -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Red Top's van makes a turn. As Abruzzo's makes the same turn behind it, the infamous Stephen Crane Projects rise in his windshield. His foot comes off the gas. As the gun car passes, he sees Jones's car slow. Teddy's car approaches from anothe direction into the Projects, and Abruzzo sees Spearman pu over. Then the laundry truck turns in, and Richie's slows to a stop, like Abruzzo's, outside the grounds of the foreboding towers. The gospel music ends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doc waits in the car while Frank buys some flowers at a cemetery flower stand. The surveillance car cruises past.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toback, in his bathrobe, glass of milk in one hand, phone the other ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somewhere in the South tower.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know that it's there.     You're sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Positive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richie, on a pay phone across down the street from the Projects, looks up at the dark South tower.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lou. We're ready to go in there knowing there's a good chance we won't all come out. That's what we're willing to do. All I'm asking you to do get me a warrant. Silence on the other end of the line ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't have a lot of time to fuck around -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll call in the warrant. And some backup. Don't go in before either gets there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This call disconnects.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girls spread and tape plastic sheeting to tabletops, then begin changing for work, which means undressing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richie and his guys wait for the warrant by their cars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long we gonna wait for it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pharmaceutical scales balance to their counterweights as the five naked, masked women cut the heroin with quinine Frank's exacting standards. Red Top puts on some coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richie stares down the street, waiting for whatever it is they're waiting for. Spearman looks at his watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It'll be here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A paper-cutter blade slices a sheet of blue cellophane. The girls at the tables, with the expertise of Cuban ciga makers, wrap pieces of the cellophane like tobacco leaves around precisely-measured 1/4-ounce drifts of Black Magic

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank's car winds up the road of the cemetery. The surveillance car comes through the main gate and parks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Several black and white and undercover cars approach, sirens off. Toback himself climbs out of one of the cars and hands Richie the search warrant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The tall buildings cast long shadows of dread on every activity below, no matter how routine: A woman pushing a stroller, guys shooting hoops, a couple arguing, kids on bikes, old men resting on a graffiti-covered bench. The unmarked cars drive slowly through it all. The place teeters on the brink of violence you can feel as gangs mo under the shadow of the towers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richie removes the cover plate of an elevator, cuts the wires, disengaging it, then leads the Amigos, followed by more detectives to a stairwell. The place is like Beirut. Debris-strewn, graffiti-covered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank walks past graves to Bumpy's. Replaces some dried flowers with fresh ones. Looks around for something to si on. Sees some wooden folding chairs around a fresher grav nearby. Doc waits by the car in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Floor by floor, they work their way up the tower like commandos, the squalor and decay and hopelessness somehow intensifying the higher up they go. Reaching the 17th floor, they listen to a strange sound before easing the fire door open enough to see a kid on a Big Wheels pedalling straight at them. He passes and the sound fades.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Half the apartment doors are gone. TVs and radios echo, voices argue, infants wail. The detectives come around a corner and see at the end of it: a couple of guys with a sawed-off shotguns sitting outside a closed door. They step back. Consider one other. Spearman volunteers with a nod, continues on alone as the others wait. He wal up to the guys with the guns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got to talk to Teddy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get the fuck out of here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the fuck is that? I got business with Teddy and it's none of your fuckin business except to knock on the fuckin door and get him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the guy stands, pumping the shotgun, Spearman yanks it hard against his throat like a garrote, forcing him to th floor. The shotgun explodes, showering plaster and pellet Jones and Abruzzo are instantly all over the other guy as Richie swings the sledgehammer into the door -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door splinters - the room already in chaos - Teddy, panicked, runs for the bedroom - the detectives crash in yelling at the girls to get down - a shot from somewhere inside wings Abruzzo - Jones and Spearman firing back - crawling across the floor like an infantrymen - Richie comes into the darkened bedroom leading with his pistol. But Teddy's gone. He sees a tapestry of a tiger o a wall. Pulls at it, finds a big hole knocked into anothe dark apartment, climbs through, sees an open door -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Richie rushes out to the hallway he can hear footfalls echoing in the stairwell. He starts down, taking the stai five at a time, chases Teddy down two flights - Teddy yanks open a door, runs down a corridor, bangs into an apartment. Richie reaches the apartment just as Teddy goes out onto an exterior balcony - Richie continues along the interior corridor, running parallel to Teddy on the balcony, who trips over some deb and garbage, looking over his shoulder for Richie - Richie cuts through another apartment to head him off, bu the door to the balcony is nailed shut. So are the window Richie looks around, grabs a small portable television an just as Teddy runs past, hurls it through a window at him hitting him in the head. He falls hard, dazed. Richie hurries through the broken window. Teddy comes to and fights back, until Richie brea his femur with his bare hands. Teddy howls in excruciatin pain -

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. DRY CLEANERS
dialogues.text: Police cars outside.    Eugene Lucas is cuffed and led aw

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More police outside Lester's place.     They cuff him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: New Jersey troopers cuff Turner Lucas and lead him away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cuffed, Earl Lucas is put in the back of a patrol car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank, on a wooden folding chair at Bumpy's grave, hears the gunning of engines and barking of cops. He turns to s Doc being handcuffed on the ground by the Towncar. Glance to a lone figure walking toward him over a rise. Richie. Richie arrives at the grave. Regards the monument to Ellsworth Johnson, and Frank sitting calmly regarding him Richie glances around the peaceful surroundings ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of trees are these? Frank looks at the trees, then at Richie, with equal serenity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think you got Frank Lucas.      You got nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richie cuts the tags off a new, inexpensive suit. Slips the jacket on, which seemed somehow to fit a little bette at the store. Cuts the tags off a tie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone throwing up in a stall. The toilet flushes, the door opens and Richie steps up to a sink, regards his fac in the mirror. Under the fluorescent lights - maybe under any kind - his skin is a shade of death. He splashes wate on it and tries to gather himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the prosecutors table, Richie steals glances at the battery of expensive attorneys over at the defense table.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The courtroom doors swing open and Richie sees Frank Luca in a tailored suit, escorted in without cuffs by an amiab looking federal marshal. As Frank moves through the gallery, Richie sees it's full the gangster's friends, many of them celebrities, who smi and greet and fawn as if the Pope has arrived. Richie has evidence tables covered with cash, weapons, stocks, bonds, property deeds, pictures of Frank's holdin heroin in blue cellophane. Frank has celebrities, community leaders, Joe Louis himse who will testify to Frank's benevolent character. The Cha hugs the heroin trafficker warmly in front of everyone an Richie wonders if he should just give up now. Richie sees it in slow motion: the hands reaching out to Frank, the pats on his back, lipsticked mouths of beautif women offering kisses and words of encouragement, his old mother giving him a hug. He watches Frank's head turn slowly, his eyes passing his phalanx of attorneys, the jury, finally settling on Richi in his cheap suit seated at the prosecutors table. Frank's eyes smile as they regard Richie, and seem to ask Can you see this - can you see what you're up against - c you see how insignificant you are? Reaching the end of the welcoming line finally, Frank brushes by Richie and disappears from view somewhere with the protective husk of his multi-million-dollar legal tea

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Roberts -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richie slowly lifts himself from his chair, steps forward turns to look at the jury that's studying him, finally fi his voice:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, your Honor.   Ladies and gentlemen -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wire mesh separates Frank from his battalion of lawyers. He glances over them to Richie being led through the larg Visiting Room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here he is, let me talk to him alone.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The attorneys get up and leave. Richie takes their place. Frank regards him a moment, offering the same knowing smi from the courtroom. Richie offers nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just heard something. I said it couldn't be true. You didn't really turn in a million dollars you found in the trunk of a car, did you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richie doesn't say. Frank searches his face for some clue to where on earth he's from.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Want me to tell you what happened to it? It ended up in cops' pockets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe? No. It did. All you did was give it to them for nothing in return. Not nothing: You got their contempt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank studies him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why'd you do that? What're you trying to prove, you're better than them? You're not better than them. You are them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't have the time or interest to listen to (this) -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You did it because it was right. That's all. Why's that hard to say? The question is would you do it again? That was a long time ago. It'd be very easy to find out. Tell me you want to find out, tell me the address, and a car will be there, the trunk loaded.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richie knows Frank isn't kidding ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank suddenly explodes -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who the fuck are you to say no to that? You think that impresses me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guards look over, then glance away once it's clear the outburst is through. Richie remains serene. Eventually -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me ask you something. You think by putting me in jail, you're going to stop even one junkie from dying? Because you won't. If it isn't me, it'll be someone else. With me or without me, nothing's going to change.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then that's the way it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have any sort of case? Or just that idiot drives for my brother. Is he your case? Because if it's just him and the powder, it's not enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you got nothing to worry about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Frank is worried, most of all by this cop who doesn't take money sitting placidly in front of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My brothers won't talk to you. My cousins. None of my family. No one but that mother fucking driver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got more than that. I got a line of people wanting to testify that stretches out the door and around the block.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bullshit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it? Tony the Bug.     Benny Two-Socks. Carmine Camanetti.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who the fuck are they? I don't know them and they don't know me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They sell dope for the Mazzano crime family. Which you all but put out of business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is who you're going to put on the stand? Guys who don't know me? Who got nothing to do with me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They have everything to do with you. And the only thing they hate more than you is what you represent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't represent nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't? Black businessman like you? Of course you do. But once you're gone, things can return to normal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at me. You looking? Can you tell by looking it would mean nothing to me if tomorrow you turned up dead?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get in line. That one stretches around the block, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank has never been so frustrated by anyone in his life. He wants to work something out with Richie obviously, but can't figure out how. Frank studies him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What can we do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what you have to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank does, but doesn't like it, and doesn't know if he c do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could give you cops, but that's not who you want, is it. You want organized crime names.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll take them, too.   I want them all.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Frank isn't sure he heard right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll take them, too? You'd go after cops? Are you serious? You'd do that? Lock up your own kind?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're not. Not the ones in business with you. They're not my kind any more than the Italians are yours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They regard one another in silence.      Richie can tell sees daylight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What can you promise me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can promise you if you lie to me about one name, you'll never get out of prison. Lie about one dollar in one offshore account, you'll never get out. You can live rich in jail the rest of your life, or poor outside it, that's what I can promise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank is silent for several moments.      Finally -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, I don't care if the feds take all my buildings, my stocks, my off-shore accounts. They can take it all, I don't care - use it to build battleships, paint bridges, whatever the fuck they want. Fight another war. But those other motherfuckers - the cops - put my money in their pockets. Millions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I believe it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank debates with himself the step he's about to take ..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to know everyone   you've met for the last twenty years.    Everyone you sold to. Every cop you ever    paid off. Every one who ever stole from   you. Every one you remember.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I remember them all.   That's not the problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The jail's aren't big enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Surveillance photographs of cops seen earlier taking envelopes of money on 116th Street and other drops go up on a new, elaborate Table of Organization - of cops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richie dismantles the Lucas Table of Organization here, taking down the photographs. As it collapses -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank puts up photographs of detectives - 347   QUICK CUTS of the same detectives, in handcuffs, le police stations past other cops watching with dread like maybe they're next - A surveillance photograph of the four Princes of the City striding down a sidewalk goes up on the cell wall - 348   FLASHCUT as three of the four SIU cops are led away from a golf course - 349   A surveillance photograph of Trupo in a black hand

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You go up here. Your "special."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Frank tapes the picture of Trupo at the top of the pyramid of corruption -

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. TRUPO'S GARAGE
dialogues.text: Trupo, coffee in hand, comes into his garage from his kitchen. Opens the garage door and sees two squad cars parked outside ... 351   A TV: A report on the indictments handed down by th Manhattan DA's office against 53 NYPD and SIU detectives

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank gathers his few personal belongings and puts them i a box. Stands with the box and waits for the cell door to open. The Table of Organization and files are gone. Legend:   Frank Lucas was convicted of Conspiracy to Distribute Narcotics and sentenced to 70 years. He served 15 of them. Legend:   Federal authorities confiscated over 250 millio dollars from him in real estate, equities and cash in US and foreign banks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richie, too, is packing, putting personal items into boxe Legend:   The day after he convicted Frank Lucas and 30 o his Country Boy relatives, Richard Roberts borrowed $400 from his credit union to help pay for a 3-day vacation to the Bahamas. Richie, carrying the box, switches off the lights and clo the door behind him on his way out. Legend:   Six months later, he quit the Prosecutors Offic to become a defense attorney. His first client was Frank Lucas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank steps out into sunlight, free but owning nothing bu the cardboard box in his arms. Looks out across the parki lot to see if anyone has come to pick him up. Sees Richie by his car, hand raised above his head like a flag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two of them stand outside Richie's car on the same corner Frank shot Tango. Frank looks up at the street sig that used to say 116th Street and 8th Avenue. Now they sa 116th Street and Frederick Douglass Boulevard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frederick Douglass Boulevard? What was wrong with just plain 8th Avenue? He considers the street itself. It too has changed. The corner groceries, as Bumpy prophesied, really are gone no

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I used to sit here with Ana in my old car. She hated it. Now I don't even have a car. Or her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank glances to where his favorite diner used to be, and across the street to where he shot Tango. It isn't a frui stand any more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just do what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The fuck is that? Just do what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a Nike store with huge paintings of Michael Jordan a the admonition "Just Do It."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sneakers.   Expensive ones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who the fuck would buy those?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A car equipped with sub-woofer bass comes booming past. Frank stares at it with the same pained look Bumpy had at the discount emporium.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your brothers know you're out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't talked to them in years. It's better that way. For them. I don't know where they are. Went back to Greensboro when they got out, I guess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richie nods.    Frank looks back at the new storefronts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What am I going to do now, be a janitor? What do I know how to do? How am I going to live?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you I wouldn't let you starve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You told me but you can barely take care of yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (glances to a pay phone on the corner) You know, one phone call, Richie, I could be back in business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The look Richie gives him calmly assures Frank if he did that it'd be the last phone he made outside prison - ever

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I won't.   I'm just saying I could.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He buttons the cuffs of the fake Members Only windbreaker Richie bought him off the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks for the clothes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're welcome.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank glances away to three young hoods coming toward the like they own the sidewalk and everything around it - bag pants, bandanas tied around their heads.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-oh. Look out. Here come the gangsters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank's right in their path but doesn't move, forcing one of them to squeeze between him and a parking meter. The gangsta looks back, is about to say something, or do something, but, examining the expression of quiet menace Frank's face, thinks better of it. The others stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The first one is still staring at Frank, but finally has good sense to let it go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They move on.    Frank glances to Richie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every idiot gets to be young once.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank zips up his Members Only jacket, props up the colla and points himself in the other direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's get out of here.
